Chief Complaint: Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**] is a 30 year old gentleman with biliary
   atresia s/p liver transplant (25 years ago) complicated by recurrent
   cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension,
   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted  with
   peritonitis s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic
   respiratory distress.
   24 Hour Events:
   Intubated for increased work of breathing in setting of hypoxic
   respiratory failure. Improved PaO2 overnight while intubated.
   HD cath placed - CVVH started to take off fluid but stopped because
   filter clotted off this AM.
   CT head for anisocoria- no acute pathology
   CT torso - new R sided effusion, new R sided opacities, old L sided
   effusion. In context of worsening clinical status and leukocytosis,
   started on cefepime, vanco, cipro.
 NON-INVASIVE VENTILATION - START [**2135-7-15**] 06:13 PM

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:17.4/41.4/1.6, ALT / AST:15/31, Alk Phos / T
   Bili:261/1.9, Differential-Neuts:90.4 %, Lymph:5.2 %, Mono:2.2 %,
   Eos:1.9 %, Lactic Acid:1.0 mmol/L, Albumin:2.7 g/dL, LDH:208 IU/L,
   Ca++:8.3 mg/dL, Mg++:2.0 mg/dL, PO4:6.4 mg/dL
   Imaging: PRELIM REPORTS
   CT head - No hemorrhage or edema
   CT chest - As on radiograph, large left effusion w/ resulting LLL and
   lingula collapse. Right lung extensive airspace opacities most
   suggestive of pulmonary edema, as etiology but infectious process not
   excluded. Similar abd/pelv findings of anasarca, ascites, irregular
   liver contour suggesting of chronic disease, and splenomegaly.
   Microbiology: [**7-16**] Sputum - no microorganisms seen
   [**7-14**] Urine cx - <[**Numeric Identifier **]
   [**7-12**] Peritoneal fluid - no growth
   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**] is a 30 year old gentleman with biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (25 years ago) complicated by recurrent cirrhosis,
   hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension,
   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted peritonitis
   s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress
   and requiring intubation last night.
   1) HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing in setting of chronic hypoxia with AA
   gradient.
   *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Worsening hypoxia with new R-sided opacities and new R pleural
   effusion leading to VQ mismatch, suspicious for PNA vs/in addition to
   increased pulmonary edema  from volume repletion in the setting of
   acute on sub-acute renal failure and oliguria. Original concern for PE
   without strong clinical evidence. Final read on LENIS pending. Started
   on vanc.cipro/cefepime due to new opacities.  In order to identify
   possible organisms, a bronchoscopy today.
   *Given concern for volume overload in setting of renal failure, CVVH
   was started overnight. Due to clotting off of filter, HD will be
   started this AM, with goal of net negative fluid balance.
   *His PaO2 has improved overnight on intubation. Last PaO2 was 117, so
   we can reduce FiO2 to 30 to reduce the risk of oxygen toxicity.
   - Wean FiO2 as tolerated.
   - HD this AM.
   - Continue vanc/cefepime/cipro until cultures return. Check renal
   dosing.
   - Check bladder pressure to rule out contribution to increased
   abdominal pressure with subsequent atelectasis/VQ mismatch.
   - Defer PE work-up or CTA for now. Follow-up final read on LENIs, tech
   note was negative for occlusive thrombus.
   - Repeat ABG's for vent or clinical changes
   2) ACIDOSIS: Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis with a delta gap
   0.75.  Metabolic acidosis may be multifactorial but likely includes
   anion gap from renal failure. [**Doctor Last Name 6492**] formula predicts PaCO2 of 38, his
   is 45, suggesting that he likely has compensatory hypercarbia and an
   additional respiratory hypercarbia, so RR was appropriately increased
   this AM from 20 to 24.
   - Recheck lytes and ABG
   - Check lactate.
   3) CIRRHOSIS: Patient with history of biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on
   transplant list.
   - Continue lactulose.
   - Continue cipro for SBP prophylaxis.
   - Continue prograf. Check prograf level tomorrow.
   4) RENAL FAILURE: Patient with history of post-strep GN now with acute
   on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   CVVH last night but stopped due to filter clot, so HD will start this
   AM.
   - Start HD this AM.
   - Continue HRS therapy with albumin 1g/kg, midodrine, octreotide.
   - Trend creatinine, UOP.
   .
   5) PLEURAL EFFUSION: hepatohydrothorax given transudate on most recent
   thoracentesis +/- volume load in setting in renal failure. Pending HD,
   consider therapeutic thoracentesis if needed to optimize respiratory
   mechanics.
   - Continue HD.
   6) ANEMIA: Patient with intermitent transfusion requirement, with last
   transfusion requirement on [**7-14**] (1 unit PRBC).  Likely has chronic
   anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct stable this AM.
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Trend hct Q12H, transfuse hct<21.
   7) ANISOCORIA: Non-contrast CTH without acute pathology and diminished
   asymmetry of pupils on exam this AM. Unclear etiology; likely drug
   effect given improvement this AM and no findings on CT.
   -Continue to follow.
   8) FEN: made NPO given respiratory distress. Nutrition consulted.
   -Start tube feeds today and follow up nutrition recommendations.
   -Continue ISS for glycemic control.
   9) PPx: Heparin SQ and PPI
   10) ACCESS
   -PICC Line - [**2135-7-15**] 07:41 PM
   -20 Gauge - [**2135-7-15**] 07:41 PM
   -Dialysis Catheter - [**2135-7-15**] 09:13 PM
   -Arterial Line - [**2135-7-15**] 10:11 PM
   11) CODE: Full (confirmed)
   12) CONTACT: Father [**Name (NI) 8405**] [**Name (NI) 8404**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8406**]
   13) DISPOSITION: ICU level of care.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: NPO, nutrition consulted for tube feeds
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2135-7-15**] 07:41 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2135-7-15**] 07:41 PM
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2135-7-15**] 09:13 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2135-7-15**] 10:11 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Need for restraints reviewed

   Communication: Father [**Name (NI) 8405**] [**Name (NI) 8404**] [**Telephone/Fax (1) 8406**]
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU

Summary:

The patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia and liver transplant, was admitted to the ICU with peritonitis and hypoxic respiratory distress. He was intubated and placed on non-invasive ventilation, but his condition worsened, and he required invasive ventilation. He has a history of recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Hypoxic respiratory distress with a PaO2 of 117 on intubation
* Worsening hypoxia with new right-sided opacities and pleural effusion
* Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis
* Chronic anemia from liver and renal failure
* Acute on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN or HRS type 1
* Pleural effusion likely due to transudate or volume overload
* Anisocoria with unclear etiology

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory distress may worsen, leading to further decline in oxygenation and ventilation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's new opacities and pleural effusion may indicate a secondary infection, which could lead to sepsis.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute on sub-acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further decline in kidney function.
4. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's liver disease and portal hypertension may lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which could worsen his respiratory status.
5. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's pleural effusion and opacities may indicate a pulmonary embolism, which could worsen his respiratory status.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anemia and liver disease may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and history of post-infectious GN may increase his risk of infection.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's oxygenation and ventilation status closely.
2. Consider bronchoscopy to identify possible organisms causing the new opacities.
3. Continue to manage the patient's acidosis with mechanical ventilation and pharmacological therapy.
4. Consider therapeutic thoracentesis to optimize respiratory mechanics.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and adjust his fluid management accordingly.
6. Consider further imaging studies, such as a computed tomography angiogram (CTA), to rule out pulmonary embolism.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and consider prophylactic therapy to prevent gastrointestinal bleeding.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, I summarize the following information:

The patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant, and various complications, was admitted with peritonitis and transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress. The patient has a complex medical history, including recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Hypoxic respiratory distress: The patient has a baseline low PaO2 of 70s, likely due to impaired VQ mismatch due to known stable L pleural effusion, ascites, and shunt from hepatopulmonary syndrome. New opacities on CT and new pleural effusion suggest PNA or increased pulmonary edema, likely secondary to acute on sub-acute renal failure and oliguria.
2. Acid-base imbalance: The patient has a mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis with a delta gap of ~1, likely representing anion gap from renal failure.
3. Liver dysfunction: The patient has a history of chronic rejection and is currently on the transplant list.
4. Renal failure: The patient has acute on sub-acute renal failure, likely secondary to ATN or HRS type 1, and is receiving CVVH therapy.
5. Pleural effusion: The patient has a transudate on most recent thoracentesis, and therapeutic thoracentesis may be necessary to optimize respiratory mechanics.
6. Anemia: The patient has chronic anemia from liver and renal failure, and is receiving intermittent transfusions.
7. Anisocoria: The patient has non-contrast CT without acute pathology, and the etiology of anisocoria is unclear.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory distress may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis risk is high due to his complex medical history and recent peritonitis diagnosis.
3. Renal failure progression: The patient's acute on sub-acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further compromise of his renal function.
4. Liver dysfunction exacerbation: The patient's chronic rejection may worsen, leading to further liver dysfunction.
5. Pulmonary edema: The patient's new opacities on CT and pleural effusion may indicate increased pulmonary edema, which can worsen his respiratory status.
6. Infection: The patient's recent peritonitis diagnosis and presence of new opacities on CT increase his risk of developing infection.
7. Anemia worsening: The patient's chronic anemia may worsen, leading to further compromise of his oxygen delivery.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, close monitoring and management of his respiratory, renal, liver, and anemia status are crucial to prevent these potential complications.

   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted peritonitis

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Distress: The patient's worsening hypoxia and increased work of breathing may lead to further respiratory compromise, potentially requiring increased ventilatory support or invasive mechanical ventilation.
2. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's bilateral rales and decreased sounds at the left base suggest pulmonary edema, which may worsen if not managed properly.
3. Anasarca: The patient's bilateral pitting edema and ascites may indicate worsening anasarca, which can lead to further respiratory compromise and increased risk of infection.
4. Renal Failure: The patient's acute on sub-acute renal failure may progress to end-stage renal disease if not managed properly, leading to increased risk of electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and mortality.
5. Infection: The patient's new opacities and pleural effusion may indicate an infectious process, which can lead to sepsis, organ dysfunction, and mortality if not managed promptly and effectively.
6. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's anemia and guaiac-positive stools suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to further anemia, hypovolemia, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
7. Liver Failure: The patient's history of liver transplant and chronic rejection may lead to further liver dysfunction, potentially causing increased bilirubin levels, coagulopathy, and decreased synthetic function.
8. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's tachycardia and decreased sounds at the left base may indicate cardiac compromise, potentially leading to further cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.
9. Neurological Complications: The patient's anisocoria and potential for increased intracranial pressure may indicate neurological compromise, potentially leading to further neurological deficits, seizures, or coma.

To mitigate these potential complications, the patient should receive close monitoring and management of their respiratory, cardiac, renal, and gastrointestinal functions. Additionally, the patient's underlying liver and kidney dysfunction should be closely monitored and managed to prevent further deterioration.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant, and multiple comorbidities, is admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory distress. The patient has a complex medical history, including recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Hypoxic respiratory distress: The patient has a baseline A-a gradient and is intubated due to increased work of breathing and minute ventilation.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient has a large left pleural effusion, ascites, and pulmonary edema, which may be contributing to decreased pulmonary reserve.
3. Acute on sub-acute renal failure: The patient has oliguria and is receiving volume, which may be contributing to increased pulmonary edema.
4. Liver dysfunction: The patient has a history of chronic liver disease and is currently on the transplant list.
5. Anemia: The patient has a history of intermittent transfusion requirement and is likely experiencing chronic anemia due to liver and renal failure.
6. Pleural effusion: The patient has a large left pleural effusion, which may be contributing to respiratory distress.
7. Acid-base imbalance: The patient has a non-gap metabolic acidosis with a delta gap of 1 and a HCO3 of 16.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress may worsen due to increased pulmonary edema or shunting from a pulmonary embolism.
2. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to his multiple comorbidities and the presence of a large pleural effusion.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute on sub-acute renal failure may worsen due to continued volume administration or other factors.
4. Liver failure: The patient's chronic liver disease may worsen, leading to liver failure.
5. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's history of porto-pulmonary hypertension and pulmonary edema may increase his risk for pulmonary embolism.
6. Infection: The patient's multiple comorbidities and the presence of a large pleural effusion may increase his risk for infection.
7. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of porto-pulmonary hypertension and liver disease may increase his risk for cardiac complications.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his respiratory, renal, and liver function. The patient's treatment plan should be tailored to address his specific needs and comorbidities, and his family should be educated on his condition and treatment plan.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**] is a 30 year old gentleman with biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (25 years ago) complicated by recurrent cirrhosis,
   hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension,
   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted peritonitis
   s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress
   and requiring intubation last night.
   1) HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing in setting of chronic hypoxia with AA
   gradient.
   *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Worsening hypoxia with new R-sided opacities and new R pleural
   effusion leading to VQ mismatch, suspicious for PNA vs/in addition to
   increased pulmonary edema  from volume repletion in the setting of
   acute on sub-acute renal failure and oliguria. Original concern for PE
   without strong clinical evidence. Final read on LENIS pending. Started
   on vanc.cipro/cefepime due to new opacities.  In order to identify
   possible organisms, a bronchoscopy today.
   *Given concern for volume overload in setting of renal failure, CVVH
   was started overnight. Due to clotting off of filter, HD will be
   started this AM, with goal of net negative fluid balance.
   *His PaO2 has improved overnight on intubation. Last PaO2 was 117, so
   we can reduce FiO2 to 30 to reduce the risk of oxygen toxicity.
   - Wean FiO2 as tolerated.
   - HD this AM.
   - Continue vanc/cefepime/cipro until cultures return.
   - Check bladder pressure to rule out contribution to increased
   abdominal pressure with subsequent atelectasis/VQ mismatch.
   - Defer PE work-up or CTA for now. Follow-up final read on LENIs, tech
   note was negative for occlusive thrombus.
   - Repeat ABG's for vent or clinical changes
   2) ACIDOSIS: Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis with a delta gap
   0.75.  Metabolic acidosis may be multifactorial but likely includes
   anion gap from renal failure. [**Doctor Last Name 6492**] formula predicts PaCO2 of 38, his
   is 45, suggesting that he likely has compensatory hypercarbia and an
   additional respiratory hypercarbia, so RR was appropriately increased
   this AM from 20 to 24.
   - Recheck lytes and ABG
   - Check lactate.
   3) CIRRHOSIS: Patient with history of biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on
   transplant list.
   - Continue lactulose.
   - Continue cipro for SBP prophylaxis.
   - Continue prograf. Check prograf level tomorrow.
   4) RENAL FAILURE: Patient with history of post-strep GN now with acute
   on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   CVVH last night but stopped due to filter clot, so HD will start this
   AM.
   - Start HD this AM.
   - Continue HRS therapy with albumin 1g/kg, midodrine, octreotide.
   - Trend creatinine, UOP.
   .
   5) PLEURAL EFFUSION: hepatohydrothorax given transudate on most recent
   thoracentesis +/- volume load in setting in renal failure. Pending HD,
   consider therapeutic thoracentesis if needed to optimize respiratory
   mechanics.
   - Continue HD.
   6) ANEMIA: Patient with intermitent transfusion requirement, with last
   transfusion requirement on [**7-14**] (1 unit PRBC).  Likely has chronic
   anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct stable this AM.
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Trend hct Q12H, transfuse hct<21.
   7) ANISOCORIA: Non-contrast CTH without acute pathology and diminished
   asymmetry of pupils on exam this AM. Unclear etiology; likely drug
   effect given improvement this AM and no findings on CT.
   -Continue to follow.
   8) FEN: made NPO given respiratory distress. Nutrition consulted.
   -Start tube feeds today and follow up nutrition recommendations.
   -Continue ISS for glycemic control.
   9) PPx: Heparin SQ and PPI
   10) ACCESS

Summary:

The patient, a 30-year-old male, is a transplant recipient with a complex medical history, including biliary atresia, liver transplant, and recurrent cirrhosis. He was admitted to the ICU with peritonitis and hypoxic respiratory distress, requiring intubation. The patient's condition has deteriorated, with new right-sided opacities and effusions, and worsening hypoxia. He is being treated with antibiotics, diuretics, and vasopressors.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxic Respiratory Distress: The patient's worsening hypoxia is a concern, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory failure and death.
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's oliguric renal failure may progress to acute kidney injury, requiring dialysis and potentially affecting his overall prognosis.
3. Infections: The patient's immunocompromised state and recent peritonitis increase his risk of developing infections, including pneumonia, sepsis, and catheter-related infections.
4. Liver Failure: The patient's chronic liver disease may worsen, leading to liver failure and potential need for re-transplantation.
5. Cardiac Complications: The patient's porto-pulmonary hypertension and chronic heart failure may worsen, leading to cardiac arrest or arrhythmias.
6. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's chronic liver disease and portal hypertension may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding, which could be life-threatening.
7. Anemia: The patient's chronic anemia may worsen, requiring frequent transfusions and potentially affecting his overall prognosis.
8. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's chronic kidney disease and liver disease may lead to electrolyte imbalances, including hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, and hypomagnesemia.
9. Respiratory Failure: The patient's worsening hypoxia and respiratory distress may lead to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation and potentially affecting his overall prognosis.
10. Sepsis: The patient's immunocompromised state and recent infections increase his risk of developing sepsis, which could be life-threatening.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**] is a 30 year old gentleman with biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (25 years ago) complicated by recurrent cirrhosis,
   hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension,
   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted peritonitis
   s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress
   and requiring intubation last night.
   1) HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing in setting of chronic hypoxia with AA
   gradient.
   *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Worsening hypoxia with new R-sided opacities and new R pleural
   effusion leading to VQ mismatch, suspicious for PNA vs/in addition to
   increased pulmonary edema  from volume repletion in the setting of
   acute on sub-acute renal failure and oliguria. Original concern for PE
   without strong clinical evidence. Final read on LENIS pending. Started
   on vanc.cipro/cefepime due to new opacities.  In order to identify
   possible organisms, a bronchoscopy today.
   *Given concern for volume overload in setting of renal failure, CVVH
   was started overnight. Due to clotting off of filter, HD will be
   started this AM, with goal of net negative fluid balance.
   *His PaO2 has improved overnight on intubation. Last PaO2 was 117, so
   we can reduce FiO2 to 30 to reduce the risk of oxygen toxicity.
   - Wean FiO2 as tolerated.
   - HD this AM.
   - Continue vanc/cefepime/cipro until cultures return. Check renal
   dosing.
   - Check bladder pressure to rule out contribution to increased
   abdominal pressure with subsequent atelectasis/VQ mismatch.
   - Defer PE work-up or CTA for now. Follow-up final read on LENIs, tech
   note was negative for occlusive thrombus.
   - Repeat ABG's for vent or clinical changes
   2) ACIDOSIS: Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis with a delta gap
   0.75.  Metabolic acidosis may be multifactorial but likely includes
   anion gap from renal failure. [**Doctor Last Name 6492**] formula predicts PaCO2 of 38, his
   is 45, suggesting that he likely has compensatory hypercarbia and an
   additional respiratory hypercarbia, so RR was appropriately increased
   this AM from 20 to 24.
   - Recheck lytes and ABG
   - Check lactate.
   3) CIRRHOSIS: Patient with history of biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on
   transplant list. -Was on cipro for SBP prophylaxis, now dosed for VAP.
   - Continue lactulose.
   - Continue prograf. Check prograf level tomorrow.
   4) RENAL FAILURE: Patient with history of post-strep GN now with acute
   on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   CVVH last night but stopped due to filter clot, so HD will start this
   AM.
   - Start HD this AM.
   - Continue HRS therapy with albumin 1g/kg, midodrine, octreotide.
   - Trend creatinine, UOP.
   .
   5) PLEURAL EFFUSION: hepatohydrothorax given transudate on most recent
   thoracentesis +/- volume load in setting in renal failure. Pending HD,
   consider therapeutic thoracentesis if needed to optimize respiratory
   mechanics.
   - Continue HD.
   6) ANEMIA: Patient with intermitent transfusion requirement, with last
   transfusion requirement on [**7-14**] (1 unit PRBC).  Likely has chronic
   anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct stable this AM.
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Trend hct Q12H, transfuse hct<21.
   7) ANISOCORIA: Non-contrast CTH without acute pathology and diminished
   asymmetry of pupils on exam this AM. Unclear etiology; likely drug
   effect given improvement this AM and no findings on CT.
   -Continue to follow.
   8) FEN: made NPO given respiratory distress. Nutrition consulted.

Summary:

The patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant, and multiple comorbidities, is admitted to the MICU with hypoxic respiratory distress, peritonitis, and sepsis. He is intubated and requires mechanical ventilation. His condition is complicated by recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma.

Potential medical complications:

1. Hypoxic respiratory distress: The patient's hypoxia is likely due to a combination of factors, including chronic hypoxia, impaired V/Q mismatch, and shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome. Worsening hypoxia may be due to new opacities and effusions, which could be caused by pneumonia, pulmonary edema, or other conditions.
2. Acidosis: The patient has mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis, which may be multifactorial. His anion gap is high, suggesting that he has metabolic acidosis, which may be due to renal failure.
3. Cirrhosis: The patient has a history of chronic liver disease, which may be contributing to his respiratory and renal failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient has acute on sub-acute renal failure, which may be due to ATN or HRS type 1. He requires dialysis, and his creatinine level is increasing.
5. Pleural effusion: The patient has a large left pleural effusion, which may be causing respiratory distress. He may require therapeutic thoracentesis to optimize his respiratory mechanics.
6. Anemia: The patient has chronic anemia, which may be due to his liver and renal failure. He requires transfusions, and his hemoglobin level is stable.
7. Anisocoria: The patient has anisocoria, which may be due to a medication effect or an underlying condition. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause.
8. Feeding: The patient is NPO, and nutrition has been consulted for tube feeds. He requires glycemic control, and his blood glucose level is being monitored.
9. Access: The patient has multiple lines and catheters, including a PICC line, dialysis catheter, and arterial line. He requires prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer.
10. Code status: The patient's code status is full code.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to address his multiple comorbidities and complications.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**] is a 30 year old gentleman with biliary atresia s/p liver

   hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension,
   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted peritonitis
   s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress
   and requiring intubation last night.
   1) HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing in setting of chronic hypoxia with AA
   gradient.
   *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Worsening hypoxia with new R-sided opacities and new R pleural
   effusion leading to VQ mismatch, suspicious for PNA vs/in addition to
   increased pulmonary edema  from volume repletion in the setting of
   acute on sub-acute renal failure and oliguria. Original concern for PE
   without strong clinical evidence. Final read on LENIS pending. Started
   on vanc.cipro/cefepime due to new opacities.  In order to identify
   possible organisms, a bronchoscopy today.
   *Given concern for volume overload in setting of renal failure, CVVH
   was started overnight. Due to clotting off of filter, HD will be
   started this AM, with goal of net negative fluid balance.

   we can reduce FiO2 to 30 to reduce the risk of oxygen toxicity.

   note was negative for occlusive thrombus.

   0.75.  Metabolic acidosis may be multifactorial but likely includes
   anion gap from renal failure. [**Doctor Last Name 6492**] formula predicts PaCO2 of 38, his
   is 45, suggesting that he likely has compensatory hypercarbia and an
   additional respiratory hypercarbia, so RR was appropriately increased
   this AM from 20 to 24.

   transplant (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on

Summary:

The patient, a 30-year-old man with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant, and various comorbidities, was admitted to the ICU with peritonitis and hypoxic respiratory distress. He was intubated and placed on non-invasive ventilation, but later required invasive ventilation due to worsening hypoxia. He has a history of recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious glomerulonephritis, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma.

The patient's condition is complicated by:

1. Hypoxic respiratory distress: Worsening hypoxia with new right-sided opacities and pleural effusion, leading to V/Q mismatch, suspicious for pneumonia or pulmonary edema.
2. Acidosis: Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis with a delta gap of 0.75, likely due to anion gap from renal failure.
3. Cirrhosis: Patient has a history of biliary atresia and liver transplant, complicated by chronic rejection.
4. Renal failure: Patient has a history of post-strep glomerulonephritis and now has acute on sub-acute renal failure, likely secondary to ATN or HRS type 1.
5. Pleural effusion: Hepatohydrothorax due to transudate on most recent thoracentesis, likely secondary to volume overload in setting of renal failure.
6. Anemia: Patient has chronic anemia from liver and renal failure, with intermittent transfusion requirements.
7. Anisocoria: Unclear etiology, likely due to drug effect given improvement this morning and no findings on CT.
8. Fever: Patient has a temperature of 37.3C (99.2F) with a range of 36.4C (97.5F) to 37.3C (99.2F) over the past 24 hours.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Pneumonia: Given the patient's history of asthma and pulmonary edema, there is a risk of developing pneumonia.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's worsening hypoxia and increased work of breathing may lead to respiratory failure.
3. Cardiac arrest: Given the patient's history of porto-pulmonary hypertension and liver disease, there is a risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Renal failure progression: The patient's acute on sub-acute renal failure may progress to chronic renal failure.
5. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and history of post-infectious glomerulonephritis make him susceptible to infection.
6. Bleeding: Given the patient's history of liver disease and portal hypertension, there is a risk of bleeding.
7. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's liver disease may lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause altered mental status and increased risk of bleeding.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiac, and renal status, as well as treatment of his underlying comorbidities.

   - CVVH to take off fluid
   - Continued vanc/cefepime/cipro until cultures return - need ID
   approval
   - Consider bronch of RUL
   - Can optimize respiratory mechanics with thoracentesis and
   paracentesis. Check bladder pressure
   - Defer PE work-up or CTA for now. Follow-up final read on LENIs, tech
   note was negative for occlusive thrombus.
   - Repeat ABG's for vent or clinical changes
   .
   # Acid-base: Likely represents a chronic gap, non-gap metabolic
   acidosis with a delta gap of 1 and a HCO3 16.  pH currently stable,
   which is suggestive that his PCO2 is compensatory, although given his
   tachypnea currently an unchanged pH and PCO2 with increased minute
   ventilation would suggest an possible increased dead space fraction.
   - Recheck lytes and ABG
   - Check lactate
   .
   # Liver: Patient with history of biliary atresia s/p liver transplant
   (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on transplant list.
   - Continue lactulose
   - Continue cipro for SBP prophylaxis.
   - Continue prograf
   .
   # Renal: Patient with history of post-strep GN now with acute on
   sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   Discussed with transplant renal, plan for HD tonight.
   - Place HD line, HD today
   - Start HRS therapy with albumin 1g/kg, midodrine, octreotide.
   - Trend creatinine, UOP.
   .
   # Pleural effusion: Likely contralateral hepatohydrothorax given
   transudate on most recent thoracentesis.
   - Will need to consider thereapeutic thoracentesis in order to optimize
   respiratory mechanics
   - Diurese
   .
   # Anemia: Patient with intermitent transfusion requirement, with last
   transfusion requirement on [**7-14**] (1 unit PRBC).  Likely has chronic
   anemia from liver and renal failure.
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Trend hct [**Hospital1 **], transfuse hct<21.
   .
   # Anisocoria: Non-contrast CTH without acute pathology. Unclear
   etiology; likely drug effect vs. physiologic anisocoria in the absence
   of findings on CT.
   .

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant (25 years ago), and subsequent complications, including recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious glomerulonephritis, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma. He was admitted with peritonitis and is currently in the MICU with hypoxic respiratory distress.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with a baseline PaO2 of 70s and increasing work of breathing. He has a large left pleural effusion and ascites, which contribute to his baseline hypoxia. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a CMV/ASSIST mode.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 12.4-10.8 K/uL
* Hct: 26.7-24.5%
* Plt: 178-147 K/uL
* Cr: 3.9-3.6 mg/dL
* TCO2: 22-24 mmol/L
* Glucose: 126-109 mg/dL
* Albumin: 2.7 g/dL
* LDH: 208 IU/L
* Ca++: 8.3 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.0 mg/dL
* PO4: 6.4 mg/dL

The patient's acid-base status is likely a chronic gap, non-gap metabolic acidosis with a delta gap of 1 and a HCO3 of 16.

The patient's liver function is compromised, with a history of chronic rejection and current liver dysfunction. He is on the transplant list.

The patient's renal function is also compromised, with acute on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN or HRS type 1. He is receiving hemodialysis and will require ongoing management.

The patient's pleural effusion is likely a contralateral hepatohydrothorax, and therapeutic thoracentesis may be necessary to optimize respiratory mechanics.

The patient's anemia is likely due to chronic liver and renal failure, and he will require ongoing transfusion support.

The patient's anisocoria is unclear, but may be due to a drug effect or physiologic anisocoria.

The patient's overall condition is critical, and he requires close monitoring and management in the ICU. Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening respiratory distress due to increased pulmonary edema or shunting.
2. Acute kidney injury or worsening chronic kidney disease.
3. Sepsis or septic shock due to ongoing infections.
4. Bleeding or hemorrhage due to coagulopathy.
5. Liver failure or worsening liver dysfunction.
6. Cardiac complications due to chronic liver disease or pulmonary hypertension.
7. Infections such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, or bloodstream infections.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to liver disease or ascites.

The patient's care plan includes:

1. Continued mechanical ventilation with optimization of respiratory mechanics.
2. Hemodialysis to manage acute on sub-acute renal failure.
3. Liver transplant evaluation and management.
4. Ongoing transfusion support for anemia.
5. Therapeutic thoracentesis for pleural effusion.
6. Close monitoring of acid-base status and electrolyte imbalances.
7. Antibiotic therapy for suspected infections.
8. Stress ulcer prophylaxis and DVT prophylaxis.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 30-year-old male who has undergone a liver transplant but suffered from rejection and is now experiencing acute renal failure and respiratory failure. The patient is mechanically ventilated and has a complex medical condition with multiple potential complications.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including acute volume overload, pulmonary hypertension, portopulmonary hypertension, and atelectasis due to abdominal distension. The patient requires continued mechanical ventilation, and bronchoscopy is planned to assess for pneumonia.
2. Pulmonary infiltrates: The patient's pulmonary infiltrates may be due to pulmonary edema or pneumonia. Bronchoscopy is planned to assess for infection, including opportunistic infection, and empirical antimicrobials are being administered.
3. Renal failure: The patient has acute renal failure, which may be due to ATN or HRS type 1. The patient is receiving midodrine and octreotide, and albumin challenge is planned as per liver and renal guidelines. Conventional hemodialysis may be necessary.
4. Fluid overload: The patient has a net volume overload, and a negative fluid balance is desired.
5. Acidosis: The patient's acidosis is attributed to acute renal failure and lactic acidosis. The patient's acidosis will be monitored during dialysis.
6. Liver failure: The patient is listed for liver transplant and is receiving lactulose and cipro for prophylaxis.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is attributed to renal failure and possible medication contribution.
8. Ascites: The patient's ascites is stable, and head CT is normal. The patient's ascites will be monitored.
9. Nutritional support: The patient requires nutritional support, and tube feeding (TF) is planned.
10. ICU care: The patient requires close monitoring in the ICU, with attention to glycemic control, lines, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

In summary, the patient has a complex medical condition with multiple potential complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and treat these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 30-year-old male who is currently intubated and mechanically ventilated in the ICU due to respiratory failure. He has a history of liver transplant failure due to rejection and is now experiencing acute renal failure and respiratory failure. The patient's condition is multifactorial, including acute volume overload in the setting of acute on chronic renal failure, pulmonary hypertension, and atelectasis due to abdominal distension. He is also immunocompromised, which increases the risk of infection and pneumonia.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 93 bpm, blood pressure of 118/71 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 97%. His respiratory support includes mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute.

The patient's laboratory results show acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 3.6 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 20 mEq/L. His liver function tests (LFTs) are also abnormal, with a total bilirubin level of 3.6 mg/dL and a direct bilirubin level of 1.9 mg/dL. His complete blood count (CBC) shows anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 7.6 g/dL and a white blood cell count of 12.4 K/uL.

The patient's plan includes continuing dialysis for net diuresis, bronchoscopy to assess for pneumonia, and empirical antimicrobials. He is also receiving midodrine and octreotide for renal failure, and lactulose and ciprofloxacin for prophylaxis against liver failure. His nutritional support includes total parenteral nutrition (TPN).

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is already intubated and mechanically ventilated, but he may still experience respiratory failure due to the underlying lung disease and the risk of pneumonia.
2. Infection: The patient is immunocompromised and at risk for infection, which could be life-threatening.
3. Sepsis: The patient's respiratory failure and renal failure increase his risk of developing sepsis.
4. Liver failure: The patient's liver function is abnormal, and he may experience liver failure if not managed properly.
5. Renal failure: The patient's renal function is impaired, and he may experience further deterioration if not managed properly.
6. Acidosis: The patient's acidosis is attributed to acute renal failure and lactic acidosis, and he may experience further deterioration if not managed properly.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is attributed to renal failure and possible contribution of medications, and he may experience further deterioration if not managed properly.

In conclusion, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**] is a 30 year old gentleman with biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (25 years ago) complicated by recurrent cirrhosis,
   hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension,
   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted peritonitis
   s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress
   and requiring intubation last night.
   1) HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing in setting of chronic hypoxia with AA
   gradient.
   *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Worsening hypoxia with new R-sided opacities and new R pleural
   effusion leading to VQ mismatch, suspicious for PNA vs/in addition to
   increased pulmonary edema  from volume repletion in the setting of
   acute on sub-acute renal failure and oliguria. Original concern for PE
   without strong clinical evidence. Final read on LENIS pending. Started
   on vanc.cipro/cefepime due to new opacities.  In order to identify
   possible organisms, a bronchoscopy today.
   *Given concern for volume overload in setting of renal failure, CVVH
   was started overnight. Due to clotting off of filter, HD will be
   started this AM, with goal of net negative fluid balance.
   *His PaO2 has improved overnight on intubation. Last PaO2 was 117, so
   we can reduce FiO2 to 30 to reduce the risk of oxygen toxicity.
   - Wean FiO2 as tolerated.
   - HD this AM.
   - Continue vanc/cefepime/cipro until cultures return. Check renal
   dosing.
   - Check bladder pressure to rule out contribution to increased
   abdominal pressure with subsequent atelectasis/VQ mismatch.
   - Defer PE work-up or CTA for now. Follow-up final read on LENIs, tech
   note was negative for occlusive thrombus.
   - Repeat ABG's for vent or clinical changes
   2) ACIDOSIS: Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis with a delta gap
   0.75.  Metabolic acidosis may be multifactorial but likely includes
   anion gap from renal failure. [**Doctor Last Name 6492**] formula predicts PaCO2 of 38, his
   is 45, suggesting that he likely has compensatory hypercarbia and an
   additional respiratory hypercarbia, so RR was appropriately increased
   this AM from 20 to 24.
   - Recheck lytes and ABG
   - Check lactate.
   3) CIRRHOSIS: Patient with history of biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on
   transplant list. -Was on cipro for SBP prophylaxis, now dosed for VAP.
   - Continue lactulose.
   - Continue prograf. Check prograf level tomorrow.
   4) RENAL FAILURE: Patient with history of post-strep GN now with acute
   on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   CVVH last night but stopped due to filter clot, so HD will start this
   AM.
   - Start HD this AM.
   - Continue HRS therapy with albumin 1g/kg, midodrine, octreotide.
   - Trend creatinine, UOP.
   .
   5) PLEURAL EFFUSION: hepatohydrothorax given transudate on most recent
   thoracentesis +/- volume load in setting in renal failure. Pending HD,
   consider therapeutic thoracentesis if needed to optimize respiratory
   mechanics.
   - Continue HD.
   6) ANEMIA: Patient with intermitent transfusion requirement, with last
   transfusion requirement on [**7-14**] (1 unit PRBC).  Likely has chronic
   anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct stable this AM.
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Trend hct Q12H, transfuse hct<21.
   7) ANISOCORIA: Non-contrast CTH without acute pathology and diminished
   asymmetry of pupils on exam this AM. Unclear etiology; likely drug
   effect given improvement this AM and no findings on CT.
   -Continue to follow.
   8) FEN: made NPO given respiratory distress. Nutrition consulted.
   -Start tube feeds today and follow up nutrition recommendations.
   -Continue ISS for glycemic control.
   9) PPx: Heparin SQ and PPI
   10) ACCESS

   -Dialysis Catheter - [**2135-7-15**] 09:13 PM

Summary:

The patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant, and various complications, was admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory distress and intubation. He has a history of chronic hypoxia, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, and porto-pulmonary hypertension. He was treated with non-invasive ventilation, invasive ventilation, and CRRT due to acute renal failure. The patient's condition has been complicated by pleural effusion, ascites, and worsening respiratory distress.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to a combination of factors, including chronic hypoxia, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, and porto-pulmonary hypertension. The patient's PaO2 has improved with intubation, but the risk of oxygen toxicity remains.
2. Acidosis: The patient has a mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis, which may be multifactorial. The patient's lactate levels should be checked, and the anion gap should be monitored.
3. Renal Failure: The patient has acute on sub-acute renal failure, likely secondary to ATN or HRS type 1. CVVH was started overnight but stopped due to filter clot, and HD will be started this morning.
4. Pleural Effusion: The patient has a hepatohydrothorax, which may be due to transudate or volume overload. A therapeutic thoracentesis may be necessary to optimize respiratory mechanics.
5. Anemia: The patient has chronic anemia from liver and renal failure. Guaiac testing should be performed on all stools, and the patient's hct should be trended every 12 hours.
6. Anisocoria: The patient has anisocoria, which may be due to a drug effect. The patient's pupils should be monitored for any changes.
7. Fluid Overload: The patient has fluid overload, which may be contributing to his respiratory distress. A fluid management plan should be implemented to minimize fluid accumulation.
8. Infection: The patient has a high risk of infection due to his immunosuppressed state. He should be monitored closely for signs of infection, and antibiotics should be started promptly if necessary.
9. Liver Function Abnormalities: The patient has liver function abnormalities, including elevated liver enzymes. Liver function tests should be monitored regularly to detect any changes.
10. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient has a high risk of nutritional deficiencies due to his malnutrition and ongoing losses. He should be monitored closely for signs of malnutrition, and nutritional supplements should be provided as necessary.

Action Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
2. Start HD this morning and continue CVVH as necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's acidosis and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's pleural effusion and consider therapeutic thoracentesis if necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's anemia and adjust his transfusion plan accordingly.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's anisocoria and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.
7. Implement a fluid management plan to minimize fluid accumulation.
8. Monitor the patient for signs of infection and start antibiotics promptly if necessary.
9. Monitor the patient's liver function and adjust his treatment plan accordingly.
10. Provide nutritional supplements as necessary to prevent malnutrition.

ed for culture specimens

s, HR 90

s.  He did received 1 unit of RBC
s during the

s.  CRRT was started at 1815 as planned using Heparin as

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**] is a 30 year old gentleman with biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (25 years ago) complicated by recurrent cirrhosis,
   hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension,
   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted peritonitis
   s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress
   and requiring intubation last night.
   1) HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing in setting of chronic hypoxia with AA
   gradient.
   *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Worsening hypoxia with new R-sided opacities and new R pleural
   effusion leading to VQ mismatch, suspicious for PNA vs/in addition to
   increased pulmonary edema  from volume repletion in the setting of
   acute on sub-acute renal failure and oliguria. Original concern for PE
   without strong clinical evidence. Final read on LENIS pending. Started
   on vanc.cipro/cefepime due to new opacities.  In order to identify
   possible organisms, a bronchoscopy today.
   *Given concern for volume overload in setting of renal failure, CVVH
   was started overnight. Due to clotting off of filter, HD will be
   started this AM, with goal of net negative fluid balance.
   *His PaO2 has improved overnight on intubation. Last PaO2 was 117, so
   we can reduce FiO2 to 30 to reduce the risk of oxygen toxicity.
   - Wean FiO2 as tolerated.
   - HD this AM.
   - Continue vanc/cefepime/cipro until cultures return. Check renal
   dosing.
   - Check bladder pressure to rule out contribution to increased
   abdominal pressure with subsequent atelectasis/VQ mismatch.
   - Defer PE work-up or CTA for now. Follow-up final read on LENIs, tech
   note was negative for occlusive thrombus.
   - Repeat ABG's for vent or clinical changes
   2) ACIDOSIS: Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis with a delta gap
   0.75.  Metabolic acidosis may be multifactorial but likely includes
   anion gap from renal failure. [**Doctor Last Name 6492**] formula predicts PaCO2 of 38, his
   is 45, suggesting that he likely has compensatory hypercarbia and an
   additional respiratory hypercarbia, so RR was appropriately increased
   this AM from 20 to 24.
   - Recheck lytes and ABG
   - Check lactate.
   3) CIRRHOSIS: Patient with history of biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on
   transplant list. -Was on cipro for SBP prophylaxis, now dosed for VAP.
   - Continue lactulose.
   - Continue prograf. Check prograf level tomorrow.
   4) RENAL FAILURE: Patient with history of post-strep GN now with acute
   on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   CVVH last night but stopped due to filter clot, so HD will start this
   AM.
   - Start HD this AM.
   - Continue HRS therapy with albumin 1g/kg, midodrine, octreotide.
   - Trend creatinine, UOP.
   .
   5) PLEURAL EFFUSION: hepatohydrothorax given transudate on most recent
   thoracentesis +/- volume load in setting in renal failure. Pending HD,
   consider therapeutic thoracentesis if needed to optimize respiratory
   mechanics.
   - Continue HD.
   6) ANEMIA: Patient with intermitent transfusion requirement, with last
   transfusion requirement on [**7-14**] (1 unit PRBC).  Likely has chronic
   anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct stable this AM.
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Trend hct Q12H, transfuse hct<21.
   7) ANISOCORIA: Non-contrast CTH without acute pathology and diminished
   asymmetry of pupils on exam this AM. Unclear etiology; likely drug
   effect given improvement this AM and no findings on CT.
   -Continue to follow.
   8) FEN: made NPO given respiratory distress. Nutrition consulted.
   -Start tube feeds today and follow up nutrition recommendations.
   -Continue ISS for glycemic control.
   9) PPx: Heparin SQ and PPI
   10) ACCESS

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**] is a 30 year old gentleman with biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (25 years ago) complicated by recurrent cirrhosis,
   hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension,
   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted peritonitis
   s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress
   and requiring intubation last night.
   1) HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing in setting of chronic hypoxia with AA
   gradient.
   *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Worsening hypoxia with new R-sided opacities and new R pleural
   effusion leading to VQ mismatch, suspicious for PNA vs/in addition to
   increased pulmonary edema  from volume repletion in the setting of
   acute on sub-acute renal failure and oliguria. Original concern for PE
   without strong clinical evidence. Final read on LENIS pending. Started
   on vanc.cipro/cefepime due to new opacities.  In order to identify
   possible organisms, a bronchoscopy today.
   *Given concern for volume overload in setting of renal failure, CVVH
   was started overnight. Due to clotting off of filter, HD will be
   started this AM, with goal of net negative fluid balance.
   *His PaO2 has improved overnight on intubation. Last PaO2 was 117, so
   we can reduce FiO2 to 30 to reduce the risk of oxygen toxicity.
   - Wean FiO2 as tolerated.
   - HD this AM.
   - Continue vanc/cefepime/cipro until cultures return. Check renal
   dosing.
   - Check bladder pressure to rule out contribution to increased
   abdominal pressure with subsequent atelectasis/VQ mismatch.
   - Defer PE work-up or CTA for now. Follow-up final read on LENIs, tech
   note was negative for occlusive thrombus.
   - Repeat ABG's for vent or clinical changes
   2) ACIDOSIS: Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis with a delta gap
   0.75.  Metabolic acidosis may be multifactorial but likely includes
   anion gap from renal failure. [**Doctor Last Name 6492**] formula predicts PaCO2 of 38, his
   is 45, suggesting that he likely has compensatory hypercarbia and an
   additional respiratory hypercarbia, so RR was appropriately increased
   this AM from 20 to 24.
   - Recheck lytes and ABG
   - Check lactate.
   3) CIRRHOSIS: Patient with history of biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on
   transplant list. -Was on cipro for SBP prophylaxis, now dosed for VAP.
   - Continue lactulose.
   - Continue prograf. Check prograf level tomorrow.
   4) RENAL FAILURE: Patient with history of post-strep GN now with acute
   on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   CVVH last night but stopped due to filter clot, so HD will start this
   AM.
   - Start HD this AM.
   - Continue HRS therapy with albumin 1g/kg, midodrine, octreotide.
   - Trend creatinine, UOP.
   .
   5) PLEURAL EFFUSION: hepatohydrothorax given transudate on most recent
   thoracentesis +/- volume load in setting in renal failure. Pending HD,
   consider therapeutic thoracentesis if needed to optimize respiratory
   mechanics.
   - Continue HD.
   6) ANEMIA: Patient with intermitent transfusion requirement, with last
   transfusion requirement on [**7-14**] (1 unit PRBC).  Likely has chronic
   anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct stable this AM.
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Trend hct Q12H, transfuse hct<21.
   7) ANISOCORIA: Non-contrast CTH without acute pathology and diminished
   asymmetry of pupils on exam this AM. Unclear etiology; likely drug
   effect given improvement this AM and no findings on CT.
   -Continue to follow.
   8) FEN: made NPO given respiratory distress. Nutrition consulted.
   -Start tube feeds today and follow up nutrition recommendations.
   -Continue ISS for glycemic control.
   9) PPx: Heparin SQ and PPI

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, the patient, Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**], is a 30-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including biliary atresia s/p liver transplant, recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma. He was admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory distress and intubation.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory distress and acute respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further respiratory compromise and potential need for more aggressive ventilatory support.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's acute kidney injury (ATN) can progress, leading to worsening renal function and potential need for dialysis.
3. Liver failure: The patient's liver function abnormalities can worsen, leading to further liver failure and potential need for liver transplantation.
4. Sepsis: The patient's septicemia can progress, leading to septic shock and potential multi-organ dysfunction.
5. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's new opacities on chest X-ray and pleural effusion can be indicative of pulmonary embolism, which can worsen respiratory function and potentially lead to cardiac complications.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia can worsen, leading to further fatigue, decreased oxygen delivery, and potential need for blood transfusions.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's liver disease and ascites can increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can worsen respiratory and cardiovascular function.
8. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's porto-pulmonary hypertension and chronic liver disease can increase the risk of cardiovascular instability, including cardiac arrhythmias and hypotension.
9. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state can increase the risk of infection, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and central line-associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).

The patient's current plan of care includes:

1. Continuing invasive ventilation with a goal of weaning FiO2 as tolerated.
2. Starting hemodialysis (HD) to manage acute kidney injury and volume overload.
3. Continuing lactulose and prograf to manage liver function abnormalities.
4. Trending creatinine, UOP, and hct to monitor renal and hematological function.
5. Performing a bronchoscopy to identify possible organisms and rule out pulmonary embolism.
6. Continuing HRS therapy with albumin, midodrine, and octreotide to manage liver function abnormalities.
7. Monitoring for signs of sepsis and potential need for antibiotic therapy.
8. Continuously assessing the patient's respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological status to adjust therapy as needed.

The patient's family has been informed of his condition, and code status has been set to full code. The patient's disposition is ICU level of care.

Summary:

The patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant, and various comorbidities, was admitted to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress and intubation. He has been diagnosed with acute respiratory failure, acute renal failure, liver function abnormalities, and anemia. The patient has a complex medical history, including recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening hypoxia: The patient's baseline low PaO2 may worsen due to impaired VQ mismatch, shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome, and new R-sided opacities.
2. Respiratory acidosis: The patient's mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis may worsen due to anion gap from renal failure.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed properly.
4. Liver function abnormalities: The patient's liver function may deteriorate further, leading to increased risk of bleeding, encephalopathy, and mortality.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to chronic bleeding, hemolysis, or bone marrow suppression.
6. Pneumonia: The patient's risk of developing pneumonia is high due to his respiratory failure, intubation, and immunosuppression.
7. Sepsis: The patient's risk of developing sepsis is high due to his respiratory failure, intubation, and immunosuppression.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding is high due to his liver disease, ascites, and portal hypertension.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Start HD this morning to manage fluid overload and correct electrolyte imbalances.
3. Continue HRS therapy with albumin, midodrine, and octreotide to manage portal hypertension and ascites.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust dialysis settings as needed.
5. Continue lactulose therapy to manage hepatic encephalopathy.
6. Monitor the patient's anemia and transfuse as needed.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust tube feedings as needed.
8. Monitor the patient's liver function and adjust therapy as needed.

Next Steps:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Review the patient's laboratory results and adjust therapy as needed.
3. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust dialysis settings as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust tube feedings as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's liver function and adjust therapy as needed.

Recommendations:

1. Consider adding a renal formula with added beneprotein to meet 100% of the patient's estimated nutritional needs.
2. Start tube feedings at 10cc/hr and advance rate by 10cc q4hrs as tolerated to goal.
3. Monitor lytes, hydration, and electrolytes and adjust tube feed regimen as needed.
4. Consider adding a gastrointestinal motility agent to manage ascites and portal hypertension.
5. Consider adding a medication to manage portal hypertension and ascites.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**] is a 30 year old gentleman with biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (25 years ago) complicated by recurrent cirrhosis,
   hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension,
   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted peritonitis
   s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress
   and requiring intubation last night.
   1) HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing in setting of chronic hypoxia with AA
   gradient.
   *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Worsening hypoxia with new R-sided opacities and new R pleural
   effusion leading to VQ mismatch, suspicious for PNA vs/in addition to
   increased pulmonary edema  from volume repletion in the setting of
   acute on sub-acute renal failure and oliguria. Original concern for PE
   without strong clinical evidence. Final read on LENIS pending. Started
   on vanc.cipro/cefepime due to new opacities.  In order to identify
   possible organisms, a bronchoscopy today.
   *Given concern for volume overload in setting of renal failure, CVVH
   was started overnight. Due to clotting off of filter, HD will be
   started this AM, with goal of net negative fluid balance.
   *His PaO2 has improved overnight on intubation. Last PaO2 was 117, so
   we can reduce FiO2 to 30 to reduce the risk of oxygen toxicity.
   - Wean FiO2 as tolerated.
   - HD this AM.
   - Continue vanc/cefepime/cipro until cultures return. Check renal
   dosing.
   - Check bladder pressure to rule out contribution to increased
   abdominal pressure with subsequent atelectasis/VQ mismatch.
   - Defer PE work-up or CTA for now. Follow-up final read on LENIs, tech
   note was negative for occlusive thrombus.
   - Repeat ABG's for vent or clinical changes
   2) ACIDOSIS: Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis with a delta gap
   0.75.  Metabolic acidosis may be multifactorial but likely includes
   anion gap from renal failure. [**Doctor Last Name 6492**] formula predicts PaCO2 of 38, his
   is 45, suggesting that he likely has compensatory hypercarbia and an
   additional respiratory hypercarbia, so RR was appropriately increased
   this AM from 20 to 24.
   - Recheck lytes and ABG
   - Check lactate.
   3) CIRRHOSIS: Patient with history of biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on
   transplant list. -Was on cipro for SBP prophylaxis, now dosed for VAP.
   - Continue lactulose.
   - Continue prograf. Check prograf level tomorrow.
   4) RENAL FAILURE: Patient with history of post-strep GN now with acute
   on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   CVVH last night but stopped due to filter clot, so HD will start this
   AM.
   - Start HD this AM.
   - Continue HRS therapy with albumin 1g/kg, midodrine, octreotide.
   - Trend creatinine, UOP.
   .
   5) PLEURAL EFFUSION: hepatohydrothorax given transudate on most recent
   thoracentesis +/- volume load in setting in renal failure. Pending HD,
   consider therapeutic thoracentesis if needed to optimize respiratory
   mechanics.
   - Continue HD.
   6) ANEMIA: Patient with intermitent transfusion requirement, with last
   transfusion requirement on [**7-14**] (1 unit PRBC).  Likely has chronic
   anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct stable this AM.
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Trend hct Q12H, transfuse hct<21.
   7) ANISOCORIA: Non-contrast CTH without acute pathology and diminished
   asymmetry of pupils on exam this AM. Unclear etiology; likely drug
   effect given improvement this AM and no findings on CT.
   -Continue to follow.
   8) FEN: made NPO given respiratory distress. Nutrition consulted.
   -Start tube feeds today and follow up nutrition recommendations.
   -Continue ISS for glycemic control.
   9) PPx: Heparin SQ and PPI

   RESPRIATORY FAILURE -- multifactorial, including acute volume overload
   in setting of acute on chronic renal failure, on backgroudn of

   RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE -- ATN versus HRS type1.  Rx Midodrine and

   resume CVVH, but may require conventional hemodialysis.
   FLUID -- net volume overload.  Desire net negative fluid balance.

   LIVER FAILURE -- currently listed for liver transplant.  Lactulose and

   ANEMIA -- attributed to renal failure, and possible contribution of
   medications.
   ANASACORIA --  stable.  Head CT WNL.  Monitor.

   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**] is a 30 year old gentleman with biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (25 years ago) complicated by recurrent cirrhosis,
   hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension,
   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted peritonitis
   s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress
   and requiring intubation last night.
   1) HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing in setting of chronic hypoxia with AA
   gradient.
   *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Worsening hypoxia with new R-sided opacities and new R pleural
   effusion leading to VQ mismatch, suspicious for PNA vs/in addition to
   increased pulmonary edema  from volume repletion in the setting of
   acute on sub-acute renal failure and oliguria. Original concern for PE
   without strong clinical evidence. Final read on LENIS pending. Started
   on vanc.cipro/cefepime due to new opacities.  In order to identify
   possible organisms, a bronchoscopy today.
   *Given concern for volume overload in setting of renal failure, CVVH
   was started overnight. Due to clotting off of filter, HD will be
   started this AM, with goal of net negative fluid balance.
   *His PaO2 has improved overnight on intubation. Last PaO2 was 117, so
   we can reduce FiO2 to 30 to reduce the risk of oxygen toxicity.
   - Wean FiO2 as tolerated.
   - HD this AM.
   - Continue vanc/cefepime/cipro until cultures return. Check renal
   dosing.
   - Check bladder pressure to rule out contribution to increased
   abdominal pressure with subsequent atelectasis/VQ mismatch.
   - Defer PE work-up or CTA for now. Follow-up final read on LENIs, tech
   note was negative for occlusive thrombus.
   - Repeat ABG's for vent or clinical changes
   2) ACIDOSIS: Mixed metabolic and respiratory acidosis with a delta gap
   0.75.  Metabolic acidosis may be multifactorial but likely includes
   anion gap from renal failure. [**Doctor Last Name 6492**] formula predicts PaCO2 of 38, his
   is 45, suggesting that he likely has compensatory hypercarbia and an
   additional respiratory hypercarbia, so RR was appropriately increased
   this AM from 20 to 24.
   - Recheck lytes and ABG
   - Check lactate.
   3) CIRRHOSIS: Patient with history of biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on
   transplant list. -Was on cipro for SBP prophylaxis, now dosed for VAP.
   - Continue lactulose.
   - Continue prograf. Check prograf level tomorrow.
   4) RENAL FAILURE: Patient with history of post-strep GN now with acute
   on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   CVVH last night but stopped due to filter clot, so HD will start this
   AM.
   - Start HD this AM.
   - Continue HRS therapy with albumin 1g/kg, midodrine, octreotide.
   - Trend creatinine, UOP.
   .
   5) PLEURAL EFFUSION: hepatohydrothorax given transudate on most recent
   thoracentesis +/- volume load in setting in renal failure. Pending HD,
   consider therapeutic thoracentesis if needed to optimize respiratory
   mechanics.
   - Continue HD.
   6) ANEMIA: Patient with intermitent transfusion requirement, with last
   transfusion requirement on [**7-14**] (1 unit PRBC).  Likely has chronic
   anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct stable this AM.
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Trend hct Q12H, transfuse hct<21.
   7) ANISOCORIA: Non-contrast CTH without acute pathology and diminished
   asymmetry of pupils on exam this AM. Unclear etiology; likely drug
   effect given improvement this AM and no findings on CT.
   -Continue to follow.
   8) FEN: made NPO given respiratory distress. Nutrition consulted.
   -Start tube feeds today and follow up nutrition recommendations.
   -Continue ISS for glycemic control.
   9) PPx: Heparin SQ and PPI

Summary:

The patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia and liver transplant, is admitted to the MICU with hypoxic respiratory distress, acute renal failure, and liver dysfunction. He has a complex medical history, including recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Respiratory failure, acute, with a PaO2 of 117 on FiO2 of 30%.
2. Acute renal failure, with a creatinine of 3.9 mg/dL and oliguria.
3. Liver dysfunction, with elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin.
4. Anemia, with a hemoglobin of 8.7 g/dL.
5. Fluid overload, with a positive fluid balance and oliguria.
6. Acidosis, with a delta gap of 0.75.
7. Anisocoria, with a non-reactive pupil on the right side.

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation, with a plan to wean FiO2 as tolerated. He is also receiving dialysis, with a plan to resume CVVH if possible. The patient is being treated with antibiotics, including vancomycin, ciprofloxacin, and cefepime, for suspected pneumonia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure, with potential for worsening hypoxia and increased work of breathing.
2. Acute kidney injury, with potential for further deterioration of renal function.
3. Liver failure, with potential for worsening liver dysfunction and encephalopathy.
4. Anemia, with potential for further decline in hemoglobin levels.
5. Fluid overload, with potential for worsening respiratory distress and cardiac failure.
6. Acidosis, with potential for worsening metabolic derangement and organ dysfunction.
7. Anisocoria, with potential for worsening vision and potential for increased risk of falls.

The patient's nutritional needs are being met with tube feedings, and his nutritional status is being monitored regularly. His fluid and electrolyte status is being closely monitored, and he is receiving albumin infusions to help with fluid management. His acid-base status is being monitored, and he is receiving lactulose for prophylaxis against liver encephalopathy.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration and potential complications.

   initial B/P was 114-120/70
s, HR 90
   Response:

   fell to 90/60, HR 80
s.  He did received 1 unit of RBC
s during the

   help with blood pressure.  Following the albumin his pressure increased
   to 110/70
s.  CRRT was started at 1815 as planned using Heparin as

s all day.  So tube feedings were stopped until absorption is
   confirmed.
