   Assessment and Plan
   Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**] is a 30 year old gentleman with biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (25 years ago) complicated by recurrent cirrhosis,
   hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension,
   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted peritonitis
   s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress
   and requiring intubation last night.
   1) HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing in setting of chronic hypoxia with AA
   gradient.
   *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Parenchymal opacities c/w PNA vs. pulmonary edema, with CXR
   improved/stable and prelim neg cx from BAL. Stable but acidemic ABG on
   FiO2 of 40%. Able to get -3L off yesterday.
   *Metabolic acidosis with appropriate  respiratory compensation
   * Bladder pressure 14, relatively low and unlikely to make much of a
   difference in atelectasis/VQ mismatch
   * Day 3 of vanc/cefepime/cipro. BAL negative, sputum negative.
   - D/C abx today due to negative cultures, follow clinical status
   - Continue dialysis with net goal of 2L off - follow up renal recs
   - Cont AC for now while getting volume off
    2) GI DYSMOTILITY, with abdominal distention, TF residuals. BM last
   night after increase in lactulose regimen. KUB no evidence of
   obstruction, large amount of stool in colon.
   - Titrate lactulose to [**12-28**] BM per day
   - Reglan PRN for nausea
   - Restart tube feeds - check residuals
   3) CIRRHOSIS: Patient with history of biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on
   transplant list. Liver following.
   - Restart cipro
   - TacroFK today, once level back Liver will decide dose of tacrolimus
   to give
   - Continue lactulose
   - Trend LFTs
   4) RENAL FAILURE: Patient with history of post-strep GN now with acute
   on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   CVVH last night but stopped due to filter clot, so HD will start this
   AM.
   - Renal recs - CVVH vs HD, goal of -2L
   - Continue HRS therapy with albumin 1g/kg, midodrine, octreotide
   - Trend chem-7
   5) Coagulopathy: Elevated PTT, off heparin currently
   - Recheck PTT off line without heparin
   6) ANEMIA: Patient with intermitent transfusion requirement, with last
   transfusion requirement on [**7-14**] (1 unit PRBC).  Likely has chronic
   anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct stable this AM at 26.9
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Trend hct Q24H, transfuse hct<21.
   7) ANISOCORIA: Non-contrast CTH without acute pathology and diminished
   asymmetry of pupils on exam this AM. Unclear etiology; likely drug
   effect given improvement this AM and no findings on CT.
   -Continue to follow.
   8) FEN: currently NPO
   - TF, check residuals
   - ISS
   9) ACCESS

   -Dialysis Catheter - [**2135-7-15**] 09:13 PM

   10) PPx: PPI, heparin, pneumoboots.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**] is a 30 year old gentleman with biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (25 years ago) complicated by recurrent cirrhosis,
   hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension,
   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted peritonitis
   s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress
   and requiring intubation last night.
   1) HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY DISTRESS: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing in setting of chronic hypoxia with AA
   gradient.
   *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Parenchymal opacities c/w PNA vs. pulmonary edema, with CXR
   improved/stable and prelim neg cx from BAL. Stable but acidemic ABG on
   FiO2 of 40%. Able to get -3L off yesterday.
   *Metabolic acidosis with appropriate  respiratory compensation
   * Bladder pressure 14, relatively low and unlikely to make much of a
   difference in atelectasis/VQ mismatch
   * Day 3 of vanc/cefepime/cipro. BAL negative, sputum negative.
   - D/C abx today due to negative cultures, follow clinical status
   - Continue dialysis with net goal of 2L off - follow up renal recs
   - Cont AC for now while getting volume off
    2) GI DYSMOTILITY, with abdominal distention, TF residuals. BM last
   night after increase in lactulose regimen. KUB no evidence of
   obstruction, large amount of stool in colon.
   - Titrate lactulose to [**12-28**] BM per day
   - Reglan PRN for nausea
   - Restart tube feeds - check residuals
   3) CIRRHOSIS: Patient with history of biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on
   transplant list. Liver following.
   - Restart cipro
   - TacroFK today, once level back Liver will decide dose of tacrolimus
   to give
   - Continue lactulose
   - Trend LFTs
   4) RENAL FAILURE: Patient with history of post-strep GN now with acute
   on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   CVVH last night but stopped due to filter clot, so HD will start this
   AM.
   - Renal recs - CVVH vs HD, goal of -2L
   - Continue HRS therapy with albumin 1g/kg, midodrine, octreotide
   - Trend chem-7
   5) Coagulopathy: Elevated PTT, off heparin currently
   - Recheck PTT off line without heparin
   6) ANEMIA: Patient with intermitent transfusion requirement, with last
   transfusion requirement on [**7-14**] (1 unit PRBC).  Likely has chronic
   anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct stable this AM at 26.9
   - Guaiac all stools
   - Trend hct Q24H, transfuse hct<21.
   7) ANISOCORIA: Non-contrast CTH without acute pathology and diminished
   asymmetry of pupils on exam this AM. Unclear etiology; likely drug
   effect given improvement this AM and no findings on CT.
   -Continue to follow.
   8) FEN: currently NPO
   - TF, check residuals
   - ISS
   9) ACCESS

Summary:

The patient is a 30-year-old male with a complex medical history, including biliary atresia, liver transplant, recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious glomerulonephritis, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma. He was admitted with peritonitis and was transferred to the MICU due to hypoxic respiratory distress and requiring intubation. He has multiple comorbidities, including chronic liver and renal failure, anemia, and coagulopathy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory distress is likely due to a combination of factors, including chronic hypoxia, impaired V/Q mismatch, and shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome. Further complications could arise from atelectasis, pneumonia, or pulmonary edema.
2. Gastrointestinal (GI) complications: The patient's GI dysmotility, abdominal distention, and TF residuals increase the risk of bowel obstruction, perforation, or bleeding. Lactulose therapy may not be effective in managing BM frequency and residuals.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute on sub-acute renal failure may progress to end-stage renal disease, requiring dialysis or transplantation. CVVH and HD may not be sufficient to manage his renal failure, and further interventions may be necessary.
4. Liver failure: The patient's chronic liver failure may worsen, leading to encephalopathy, bleeding, or sepsis. Liver transplantation may be necessary to manage his liver failure.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, requiring frequent transfusions. Iron deficiency anemia or other types of anemia may develop, requiring additional therapy.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may increase the risk of bleeding or thrombosis. Further evaluation and management of his coagulopathy are necessary.
7. Infections: The patient's immunocompromised state increases his risk of developing infections, including sepsis, pneumonia, or UTIs. Monitoring for signs of infection and prompt treatment are essential.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's porto-pulmonary hypertension and chronic liver and renal failure may increase his risk of cardiovascular complications, including arrhythmias, heart failure, or cardiac arrest.

Given the patient's complex medical history and comorbidities, close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant, and various complications, is currently in the ICU for hypoxic respiratory distress and intubation.

The patient's condition is complicated by:

1. Hypoxic respiratory distress: The patient's baseline PaO2 is in the 70s, likely due to impaired V/Q mismatch, atelectasis from ascites, and shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
2. GI dysmotility: The patient has abdominal distension, TF residuals, and has had a bowel movement last night after increasing lactulose. KUB shows no evidence of obstruction, and there is a large amount of stool in the colon.
3. Cirrhosis: The patient has a history of biliary atresia and chronic rejection, and is currently on the transplant list. Liver function tests are being trended.
4. Renal failure: The patient has acute on sub-acute renal failure, likely secondary to ATN or HRS type 1. CVVH was stopped due to filter clot, and HD will start this morning.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated PTT, and is off heparin currently.
6. Anemia: The patient has intermittent transfusion requirements and likely has chronic anemia from liver and renal failure.
7. Anisocoria: The patient has non-contrast CT without acute pathology and diminished asymmetry of pupils on exam this morning, likely due to drug effect.
8. Fen: The patient is currently NPO and has a TF, which is being checked for residuals.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening hypoxic respiratory distress
* Increased risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP)
* Development of sepsis or septic shock
* Increased risk of bleeding due to coagulopathy
* Worsening renal failure or need for dialysis
* Development of liver failure or need for liver transplant
* Increased risk of anemia or bleeding due to chronic liver and renal failure
* Development of electrolyte imbalances or acid-base disorders
* Increased risk of aspiration or respiratory failure due to GI dysmotility and abdominal distension.

The patient's care plan includes:

* Continuing lactulose to promote bowel movements
* Restarting tube feeds and checking residuals
* Trending liver function tests and monitoring for signs of liver failure
* Continuing CVVH or HD for renal failure
* Monitoring for signs of coagulopathy and bleeding
* Trending hemoglobin and hematocrit levels and transfusing as necessary
* Monitoring for signs of anemia and bleeding
* Continuing to monitor for signs of respiratory failure and aspiration.

Summary:

The patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant, and multiple complications, is admitted to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory distress and requires intubation. He has a complex medical history, including recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma.

The patient's current condition includes:

* Hypoxic respiratory distress with a PaO2 of 70s and increased work of breathing
* Metabolic acidosis with appropriate respiratory compensation
* Bladder pressure of 14, which is relatively low and unlikely to make a significant difference in atelectasis/VQ mismatch
* GI dysmotility with abdominal distention, TF residuals, and a large amount of stool in the colon
* Cirrhosis with chronic rejection and a history of liver transplant
* Renal failure with acute on sub-acute kidney injury and a need for dialysis
* Coagulopathy with elevated PTT
* Anemia with intermittent transfusion requirement
* Anisocoria with unclear etiology

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory distress and increased work of breathing may lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
2. Sepsis: The patient's history of post-infectious GN and recurrent infections may increase his risk of developing sepsis.
3. Liver failure: The patient's cirrhosis and chronic rejection may lead to liver failure if not managed properly.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute on sub-acute kidney injury may worsen if not managed properly, leading to renal failure.
5. GI bleeding: The patient's GI dysmotility and abdominal distention may increase his risk of GI bleeding.
6. Pulmonary edema: The patient's hepato-pulmonary syndrome and porto-pulmonary hypertension may lead to pulmonary edema if not managed properly.
7. Infection: The patient's history of post-infectious GN and recurrent infections may increase his risk of developing new infections.
8. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications.
9. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may increase his risk of bleeding if not managed properly.

Plan:

1. Continue to manage the patient's hypoxic respiratory distress with mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy.
2. Monitor the patient's acid-base status and adjust his ventilation and oxygen therapy as needed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's GI dysmotility with lactulose and Reglan as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's liver function and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
5. Continue to manage the patient's renal failure with dialysis and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's coagulopathy and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's anemia and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
8. Consider the patient's potential for sepsis and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
9. Consider the patient's potential for liver failure and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
10. Consider the patient's potential for renal failure and adjust his treatment plan as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 30-year-old male who has undergone a liver transplant due to rejection. He is currently experiencing respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and liver function abnormalities.

The patient's respiratory status is critical, with a diagnosis of acute respiratory failure not attributed to ARDS. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a FiO2 of 40% and PEEP of 5 cmH2O. His ABG results show a pH of 7.40, PaO2 of 367, and PaCO2 of 34.

The patient's renal status is also critical, with a diagnosis of acute renal failure. He is receiving CVVH and has a net diuresis. His creatinine levels have been fluctuating, ranging from 2.3 to 2.8 mg/dL.

The patient's liver function is abnormal, with elevated liver enzymes and a diagnosis of liver failure. He is currently listed for liver transplant and is receiving lactulose and Cipro for prophylaxis.

The patient's nutritional status is compromised, with high residuals and initial difficulty with TF. However, his bowels are now moving, and he is receiving nutritional support.

The patient's overall condition is critical, and he is at risk for various medical complications. Some potential complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he is at risk for further deterioration. He may require more aggressive ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's renal function is compromised, and he is at risk for further deterioration. He may require more aggressive dialysis or continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT).
3. Sepsis: The patient has a diagnosis of acute respiratory failure and acute renal failure, which may increase his risk for sepsis.
4. Liver failure: The patient's liver function is abnormal, and he is at risk for further deterioration. He may require more aggressive treatment for liver failure, such as liver transplantation.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's respiratory and renal failure may increase his risk for cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrest or arrhythmias.
6. Infections: The patient is at risk for infections, particularly pneumonia, given his respiratory status and the use of empirical antimicrobials.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's abdominal distension and respiratory failure may increase his risk for gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's sedation and respiratory failure may increase his risk for neurological complications, such as seizures or brain damage.

In conclusion, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

* Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's use of anticoagulation therapy and the presence of coagulopathy may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient is a critically ill individual with respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and liver function abnormalities. They are currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. Their vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 35.9C, heart rate of 71 bpm, and blood pressure of 142/83 mmHg. They have a central venous catheter and are receiving fluids, antibiotics, and pain management medications.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if their lung function does not improve, leading to further hypoxemia and hypercapnia.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic renal failure if they do not receive adequate treatment, leading to electrolyte imbalances and potential cardiovascular complications.
3. Liver Function Abnormalities: The patient's liver function abnormalities may indicate underlying liver damage or disease, which could lead to coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and other complications.
4. Infection: The patient's presence of a central venous catheter and dialysis catheter increases their risk of developing catheter-related infections, such as sepsis and endocarditis.
5. Cardiac Complications: The patient's underlying medical conditions, such as acute renal failure and liver function abnormalities, may increase their risk of developing cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias and heart failure.
6. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's presence of a nasogastric tube and risk of gastrointestinal bleeding may indicate underlying gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's underlying medical conditions, such as liver function abnormalities and electrolyte imbalances, may increase their risk of developing neurological complications, such as seizures, coma, and encephalopathy.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of their respiratory, renal, and liver function to prevent complications and optimize their outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 30-year-old male who is critically ill with respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and liver function abnormalities. He has a history of liver transplant failure due to rejection and is currently listed for liver transplant. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 100%. He has a high volume overload, with a total fluid input of 3,276 mL and a total fluid output of 6,359 mL over the past 24 hours. His blood pressure is 142/83 mmHg, and his heart rate is 71 beats per minute. He has a central venous pressure of 13 mmHg and a bladder pressure of 14 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, lactate dehydrogenase, and liver enzymes, with a decreased albumin level. His creatinine level is 2.8 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen level is 19 mg/dL. His arterial blood gas analysis shows a pH of 7.40, a partial pressure of oxygen of 367 mmHg, and a partial pressure of carbon dioxide of 34 mmHg.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, including acute volume overload, acute on chronic renal failure, pulmonary hypertension, portopulmonary hypertension, and atelectasis due to abdominal distension. He is at risk for further respiratory deterioration, including ventilator-associated pneumonia and respiratory acidosis.
2. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely due to acute tubular necrosis or hepatorenal syndrome type 1. He is at risk for further renal deterioration, including electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and need for dialysis.
3. Liver failure: The patient's liver failure is likely due to acute liver failure or chronic liver disease. He is at risk for further liver deterioration, including encephalopathy, bleeding, and need for liver transplantation.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate dehydrogenase levels suggest the possibility of sepsis. He is at risk for further septic complications, including organ failure and death.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's abdominal distension and elevated liver enzymes suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal bleeding. He is at risk for further bleeding, including hematemesis and melena.
6. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and lactate dehydrogenase levels suggest the possibility of infection. He is at risk for further infection, including ventilator-associated pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and bloodstream infection.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia and liver transplant, is currently admitted to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory failure and increased work of breathing requiring intubation.

The patient's current condition is complex and multi-factorial, with several potential medical complications that can arise. Some of the key issues include:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's baseline low PaO2 is likely due to impaired V/Q mismatch due to known stable L pleural effusion and atelectasis from ascites, as well as shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome. The patient's CXR shows moderate bilateral pleural effusions and increased density in the right perihilar and right apical regions, consistent with worsening consolidation, probably pneumonia.
2. GI dysmotility: The patient has abdominal distention, TF residuals, and a large amount of stool in the colon, suggesting GI dysmotility. The patient's KUB is negative for obstruction, and the team plans to restart tube feeds, hold for residuals over 150, and make the NG post-pyloric.
3. Cirrhosis: The patient has a history of biliary atresia and liver transplant, complicated by chronic rejection. The patient is currently on the transplant list, and the team plans to continue lactulose and trend LFTs.
4. Renal failure: The patient has a history of post-strep GN and acute on sub-acute renal failure, likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1. The patient is currently on CVVH, and the team plans to follow up with renal recs and trend chem-7 labs.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated PTT, off heparin currently, and the team plans to continue trending PTT.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is slowly trending down over the past week, and the team plans to continue trending platelet counts.
7. Anemia: The patient has intermittent transfusion requirements and likely has chronic anemia from liver and renal failure. The team plans to trend Hct Q24H and transfuse Hct <21.
8. Anisocoria: The patient has non-contrast CT without acute pathology and diminished asymmetry of pupils on exam this AM, likely due to a drug effect given the improvement this AM and no findings on CT.
9. Feeding tube management: The patient's feeding tube is post-pyloric, and the team plans to check residuals and restart tube feeds when residuals are less than 150cc.
10. Access: The patient has multiple access lines, including PICC line, dialysis catheter, and arterial line.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

* Respiratory failure and worsening hypoxia
* GI bleeding and perforation
* Liver failure and hepatic encephalopathy
* Renal failure and acute kidney injury
* Coagulopathy and bleeding
* Thrombocytopenia and bleeding
* Anemia and decreased oxygen delivery
* Anisocoria and pupillary asymmetry
* Feeding tube complications, such as tube blockage or displacement
* Access line complications, such as infection or bleeding.

Given the patient's complex medical condition, close monitoring and management of these potential complications will be crucial to prevent further deterioration and ensure the patient's best possible outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

The patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia and liver transplant 25 years ago, is admitted to the ICU with peritonitis, hypoxic respiratory failure, and increased work of breathing requiring intubation. He has a complex medical history, including recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient has a baseline low PaO2 of 70s, likely due to impaired V/Q mismatch, atelectasis from ascites, and shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
2. Gastrointestinal dysmotility: The patient has abdominal distention, TF residuals, and a large amount of stool in the colon.
3. Cirrhosis: The patient has a history of chronic rejection and is currently on the transplant list.
4. Renal failure: The patient has acute on sub-acute renal failure, likely secondary to ATN or HRS type 1, and is receiving CVVH.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient has elevated PTT, off heparin currently, and trending down.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a slow decline in platelet count over the past week, off heparin except for flushes.
7. Anemia: The patient has intermittent transfusion requirements and likely has chronic anemia from liver and renal failure.
8. Anisocoria: The patient has non-contrast CT without acute pathology and diminished asymmetry of pupils on exam, likely due to a drug effect.
9. Other medical issues: The patient has a history of post-strep GN, asthma, and nephrotic syndrome.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure may worsen, leading to further respiratory distress.
2. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's gastrointestinal dysmotility and ascites may lead to bleeding complications.
3. Renal failure progression: The patient's acute on sub-acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further compromise of his renal function.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further compromise of his oxygen delivery.
7. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state may lead to further infection, including pneumonia or sepsis.
8. Hepatic failure: The patient's liver function may worsen, leading to further compromise of his liver function.

Given the patient's complex medical history and current condition, it is essential to closely monitor his respiratory, gastrointestinal, renal, and liver function, as well as his coagulopathy, thrombocytopenia, and anemia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multiple organ failures, including respiratory, renal, and liver failure. The patient is mechanically ventilated with a tidal volume of 400 mL, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's hemodynamic status is stable, with a mean arterial pressure of 136 mmHg, central venous pressure (CVP) of 9 mmHg, and cardiac output of 8.7 L/min. The patient's renal function is compromised, with a creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL and a urine output of 186 mL.

The patient's liver function is abnormal, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 85 mg/dL and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 1.5 mg/dL. The patient's nutritional status is compromised, with a total parenteral nutrition (TPN) order of NovaSource Renal (Full) at a rate of 10 mL/hour.

The patient's pain control is managed with fentanyl and midazolam infusions. The patient's blood glucose level is within the normal range, and the patient is being monitored for glycemic control.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status can deteriorate further, leading to hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and respiratory acidosis.
2. Renal failure: The patient's renal function can continue to deteriorate, leading to further azotemia, electrolyte imbalances, and acidosis.
3. Liver failure: The patient's liver function can continue to deteriorate, leading to further encephalopathy, bleeding diathesis, and coagulopathy.
4. Infections: The patient's compromised immune status and prolonged ICU stay increase the risk of nosocomial infections, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), catheter-related bloodstream infections, and urinary tract infections.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's hemodynamic status can deteriorate further, leading to hypotension, hypertension, and cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's compromised nutritional status can lead to further malnutrition, electrolyte imbalances, and organ dysfunction.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's liver failure and coagulopathy increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock and further organ dysfunction.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve the patient's outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual with multi-organ dysfunction, including respiratory failure, liver failure, and renal failure.

The patient's respiratory status is being managed with mechanical ventilation, with a tidal volume of 400 mL, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O. The patient's oxygen saturation is 99%, and their arterial blood gas (ABG) results indicate a pH of 7.47, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) of 31 mmHg, and partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) of 111 mmHg.

The patient's liver function is abnormal, with elevated levels of aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT). Their liver enzymes are:

* AST: 85 mg/dL
* ALT: 103 mg/dL

The patient's renal function is also impaired, with acute kidney injury (AKI) and a creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL. Their urine output is 186 mL over the past 24 hours.

The patient's pain is being managed with fentanyl and midazolam infusions. They are also receiving calcium gluconate, potassium chloride, and heparin sodium infusions as part of their ICU care.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's multi-organ dysfunction.
3. Hepatic encephalopathy due to the patient's liver failure.
4. Renal failure progression or dialysis complications.
5. Pulmonary edema due to fluid overload or cardiac dysfunction.
6. Cardiovascular instability due to hypovolemia, sepsis, or cardiac dysfunction.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to stress ulceration or liver failure.
8. Infection or sepsis due to the patient's immunocompromised state.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to identify any potential complications early and initiate appropriate interventions.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with multi-organ dysfunction, including respiratory failure, liver failure, and renal failure. The patient is intubated and mechanically ventilated, with a respiratory rate set at 24 breaths per minute and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 77 beats per minute, blood pressure of 136/73 mmHg, and a temperature of 36.7C (98F). The patient's fluid balance is being monitored, with a total input of 2,710 mL and a total output of 6,176 mL over the past 24 hours.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 10.6 K/uL, a hemoglobin level of 8.0 g/dL, and a platelet count of 86 K/uL. The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 85 mg/dL and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 1.5 mg/dL. The patient's renal function is also impaired, with a creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's multi-organ dysfunction and abnormal laboratory results suggest the possibility of sepsis. The patient's respiratory failure, liver failure, and renal failure may be related to sepsis.
2. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory failure and abnormal chest radiograph (not provided) suggest the possibility of ARDS.
3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's renal failure and abnormal laboratory results suggest the possibility of AKI.
4. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's liver failure and abnormal liver function tests suggest the possibility of hepatic encephalopathy.
5. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory failure and abnormal chest radiograph (not provided) suggest the possibility of pneumonia.
6. Catheter-related bloodstream infection: The patient's presence of central venous catheters and dialysis catheters increases the risk of catheter-related bloodstream infection.
7. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient's presence of a PICC line and dialysis catheter increases the risk of DVT.
8. Stress ulcer: The patient's presence of a stress ulcer prophylaxis suggests the possibility of stress ulcer.
9. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's presence of a mechanical ventilator increases the risk of VAP.

These potential medical complications will require close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration of the patient's condition.

Summary:

The patient is a 30-year-old male who underwent a liver transplant that failed due to rejection. He is currently experiencing acute renal failure, respiratory failure, and liver function abnormalities. He is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation, and is undergoing continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) and dialysis. He has a history of pulmonary hypertension, portopulmonary hypertension, and atelectasis due to abdominal distension.

The patient's current condition is multifactorial, including acute volume overload, acute on chronic renal failure, pulmonary hypertension, and atelectasis. He is at risk for further complications, including pulmonary infiltrates, acute tubular necrosis, and hepatic encephalopathy.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pulmonary infiltrates: The patient is at risk for developing pulmonary infiltrates due to his history of pulmonary hypertension and atelectasis.
2. Acute tubular necrosis (ATN): The patient's acute renal failure may progress to ATN, which can lead to chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
3. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's liver function abnormalities may lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which can cause confusion, disorientation, and even coma.
4. Sepsis: The patient's compromised immune system and presence of indwelling catheters make him at risk for developing sepsis.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's liver function abnormalities and portal hypertension may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure may progress to chronic respiratory failure, which can lead to respiratory muscle weakness and dependence on mechanical ventilation.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's pulmonary hypertension and chronic kidney disease may lead to cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias and heart failure.
8. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's compromised gut function and liver dysfunction may lead to malnutrition and deficiencies in essential nutrients.
9. Infections: The patient's compromised immune system and presence of indwelling catheters make him at risk for developing infections, including bloodstream infections and pneumonia.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these complications and improve his outcome.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 30-year-old male who has undergone a liver transplant, which failed due to rejection. He is currently experiencing acute renal failure, respiratory failure, and liver function abnormalities.

The patient's current medical condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: multifactorial, including acute volume overload, pulmonary hypertension, portopulmonary shunt, and atelectasis due to abdominal distension. The plan is to continue mechanical ventilation, monitor ABG and SaO2, and maintain SaO2 >90%.
* Renal failure: acute, possibly due to ATN or HRS type 1. The patient is receiving midodrine and octreotide, and an albumin challenge is planned. Hepatology wants to continue CVVH and may switch to HD in the next 24-48 hours.
* Liver failure: currently listed for liver transplant. The patient is receiving lactulose and ciprofloxacin for prophylaxis, and his Prograf level is low.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.9C (98.4F)
* Heart rate: 77 beats per minute (59-103 beats per minute)
* Blood pressure: 136/73 mmHg (98-160/93 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 24 inspirations per minute (18-27 inspirations per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 99%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: CVP 9 mmHg (9-16 mmHg)

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* White blood cell count: 10.6 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 25.1%
* Platelet count: 86 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.7 mg/dL (1.6-1.5 mg/dL)
* Total CO2: 22 mmHg (24-25 mmHg)
* Glucose: 99 mg/dL (85-104 mg/dL)
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR 18.4/60.2/1.7, ALT/AST 8-17, Alk Phos/TBili 231/1.7, differential-neuts 86.6%, lymph 6.8%, mono 1.1%, eos 5.4%, lactic acid 1.5 mmol/L, albumin 3.1 g/dL, LDH 150 IU/L, Ca++ 8.1 mg/dL, Mg++ 2.0 mg/dL, PO4 1.5 mg/dL.

The patient's nutritional support is being provided through a TF, initially high residuals improved but now worse again. The plan is to check KUB serial abdominal exams and may need a post-pyloric feeding tube.

The patient's potential medical complications are:

* Respiratory failure: further deterioration of lung function, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
* Renal failure: worsening of kidney function, acute tubular necrosis (ATN), and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).
* Liver failure: further deterioration of liver function, liver failure, and liver-related complications such as bleeding and infection.
* Nutritional support: malnutrition, refeeding syndrome, and gastrointestinal complications such as diarrhea and nausea.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Respiratory support: mechanical ventilation, ABG monitoring, and maintenance of SaO2 >90%.
* Renal support: CVVH, midodrine, octreotide, and albumin challenge.
* Liver support: lactulose and ciprofloxacin for prophylaxis, and Prograf level adjustment.
* Nutritional support: TF and possible post-pyloric feeding tube.
* Prophylaxis: DVT prophylaxis, stress ulcer prophylaxis, and VAP prophylaxis.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU.

   stable.

   anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct stable.
   - Trend hct Q24H, transfuse hct<21.

   asymmetry of pupils on exam this AM. Unclear etiology; likely drug
   effect given improvement this AM and no findings on CT.

Summary:

The patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant, and multiple comorbidities, was admitted to the ICU for hypoxic respiratory failure and increased work of breathing requiring intubation. He has a history of recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma. The patient's current condition is characterized by:

* Hypoxic respiratory failure with a baseline low PaO2 of 70s, likely due to impaired VQ mismatch, atelectasis, and shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome
* Abdominal distension, TF residuals, and large amounts of stool in the colon, suggesting GI dysmotility
* Acute renal failure, likely secondary to ATN or HRS type 1, with CVVH for now
* Coagulopathy with elevated PTT, off heparin currently
* Thrombocytopenia, trending down over the past week, generally stable
* Anemia, likely chronic from liver and renal failure
* Anisocoria, likely due to drug effect
* Fever, with a temperature of 36.7C (98F)

Plan:

1. Continue CVVH and monitor for signs of improvement in renal function
2. Wean sedation as tolerated and restraints as needed
3. Restart tube feeds and hold for residuals over 150cc
4. Make NG post-pyloric and titrate lactulose to 12-28 BM per day
5. Trend LFTs and continue lactulose
6. Continue cipro prophylaxis and monitor for signs of infection
7. Trend chem-7 and monitor for signs of liver dysfunction
8. Continue to monitor for signs of bleeding and anemia
9. Monitor for signs of anisocoria and adjust treatment as needed
10. Follow up with liver and renal specialists for further management

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening respiratory failure due to inadequate ventilation or underlying lung disease
2. Sepsis or infection due to inadequate antibiotic therapy or underlying immunosuppression
3. Further deterioration of renal function leading to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease
4. Bleeding or hemorrhage due to coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia
5. Anemia or bleeding due to inadequate transfusion support
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to GI dysmotility or underlying liver disease
7. Development of hepatic encephalopathy due to liver dysfunction
8. Cardiovascular instability or arrhythmias due to underlying liver disease or electrolyte imbalances
9. Infection or sepsis due to inadequate wound care or underlying immunosuppression
10. Delayed or inadequate treatment of underlying conditions, such as liver or renal failure.

Summary:

The patient is a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant, and multiple comorbidities, including cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious glomerulonephritis, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma. He was admitted to the ICU with hypoxic respiratory failure and increased work of breathing requiring intubation. The patient has undergone CVVH and has been receiving various medications, including tacrolimus, midazolam, and fentanyl.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: Hypoxic respiratory failure with a PaO2 of 308 mmHg on FiO2 of 40%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a Vt of 400 mL, RR of 20, and PEEP of 5 cmH2O.
* Cardiovascular status: The patient has a heart rate of 65 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 143/80 mmHg.
* Neurological status: The patient is sedated and intubated.
* Gastrointestinal status: The patient has abdominal distension and is receiving tube feeds.
* Renal status: The patient has acute renal failure and is receiving CVVH.
* Hematological status: The patient has thrombocytopenia and is receiving platelet transfusions.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure may worsen due to his underlying chronic hypoxia and shunt from the hepatopulmonary syndrome.
2. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's abdominal distension and hypoechoic bowel wall may indicate bowel obstruction or perforation.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic renal failure if not managed appropriately.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen due to his underlying liver disease and may increase the risk of bleeding.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's elevated PTT may indicate a bleeding disorder, which may worsen if not managed appropriately.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen due to his underlying chronic liver and renal failure.
7. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state may increase the risk of infection, particularly with opportunistic pathogens such as Pneumocystis jirovecii.

Assessment and plan:

1. Continue CVVH with a goal of -150 cc/hr to optimize the patient's respiratory status.
2. Wean the patient off mechanical ventilation and consider extubation if the patient's respiratory status improves.
3. Continue tube feeds and advance as tolerated to ensure adequate nutrition.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust CVVH and dialysis as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's platelet count and transfuse as necessary to prevent bleeding.
6. Monitor the patient's PTT and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary to prevent bleeding or thrombosis.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's anemia and transfuse as necessary to maintain a hemoglobin level of 21% or higher.
8. Consider prophylactic antibiotics to prevent opportunistic infections.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and adjust antiretroviral therapy as necessary to prevent liver damage.

Summary:

The patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia and liver transplant, was admitted to the MICU with hypoxic respiratory failure and increased work of breathing requiring intubation. He has a complex medical history, including recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: Hypoxic respiratory failure with a PaO2 of 308 mmHg on FiO2 40%. He is on CVVH with a net negative fluid balance of 3 L.
* Gastrointestinal: Abdominal distension, TF residuals, and hypoechoic bowel sounds. Tube feeds have been restarted, and the plan is to advance to 50 cc/hr as tolerated.
* Liver: Cirrhosis with a history of chronic rejection. The patient is on the transplant list and is receiving tacrolimus.
* Renal: Acute on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN or HRS type 1. CVVH was started, and the plan is to continue it for now to optimize respiratory status.
* Coagulopathy: Elevated PTT, but no active signs of bleeding or thrombosis.
* Anemia: Chronic anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct is stable.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure may worsen due to his underlying liver and renal disease.
2. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's abdominal distension and TF residuals may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding.
3. Liver failure: The patient's cirrhosis may worsen, leading to liver failure.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute on sub-acute renal failure may worsen, leading to end-stage renal disease.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's elevated PTT may lead to bleeding or thrombosis.
6. Anemia: The patient's chronic anemia may worsen due to his underlying liver and renal disease.
7. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state may lead to infection, particularly pneumonia.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's porto-pulmonary hypertension may lead to cardiovascular complications such as heart failure or arrhythmias.

Plan:

1. Continue CVVH with a net negative fluid balance of 3 L to optimize respiratory status.
2. Wean vent to PSV and attempt extubation this PM.
3. Continue to trend plt and PTT.
4. Start clotrimazole prophylaxis for PCP.
5. Coordinate tacrolimus level checks with pharmacy.
6. Trend LFTs and Hct.
7. Continue lactulose and titrate to 12-28 BM per day.
8. Advance tube feeds to 50 cc/hr as tolerated.
9. Monitor for signs of bleeding or thrombosis.
10. Monitor for signs of infection.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

The patient, a 30-year-old male, is critically ill and intubated in the ICU due to respiratory failure, liver failure, and renal failure. He has a history of liver transplant failure due to rejection and is currently listed for another liver transplant. He has acute renal failure, possibly due to ATN or HRS type 1, and is receiving treatment with Midodrine and Octreotide.

The patient's respiratory status is complex, with multifactorial causes including acute volume overload, pulmonary hypertension, portopulmonary hypertension, and atelectasis due to abdominal distension. He has been aggressively diuresed and switched to PSV, with a goal of weaning drips and attempting extubation later in the day.

The patient's liver function is abnormal, and he is receiving lactulose and Cipro for prophylaxis. His Prograf level is low, and he will need to speak with pharmacy about adjusting.

The patient's nutritional support is being provided through tube feeds, and his glycemic control is being monitored.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening of respiratory failure, potentially leading to ARDS or respiratory arrest.
2. Progression of liver failure, potentially leading to hepatic encephalopathy, bleeding, or sepsis.
3. Continued acute renal failure, potentially leading to electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, or anuria.
4. Infection, potentially due to the patient's immunocompromised state or the presence of invasive lines and catheters.
5. Sepsis, potentially due to the patient's multi-organ dysfunction.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding, potentially due to the patient's liver failure and abdominal distension.
7. Cardiovascular instability, potentially due to the patient's pulmonary hypertension and acute volume overload.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve his chances of recovery.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 30-year-old male who has undergone a liver transplant, which failed due to rejection. He is currently experiencing acute renal failure, respiratory failure, and liver function abnormalities.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.6C (97.9F)
* Heart rate: 77 bpm (64-101 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 147/86 mmHg (111-152/90 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%
* CVP: 12 mmHg (8-16 mmHg)

The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and has a respiratory support plan in place, including a tidal volume of 400 mL, a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 9.8 K/uL (9.5 K/uL)
* Hemoglobin: 8.1 g/dL
* Platelet count: 93 K/uL (94 K/uL)
* Creatinine: 1.5 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 26 mEq/L
* Sodium: 135 mEq/L
* Potassium: 4.2 mEq/L
* Chloride: 102 mEq/L
* Albumin: 2.9 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 1.3 mmol/L

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Alteration in nutrition: The patient is receiving nutritional support through a total parenteral nutrition (TPN) solution.
* Respiratory failure: The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and has a respiratory support plan in place.
* Renal failure: The patient is receiving dialysis and has a plan to continue dialysis for net diuresis.
* Pain control: The patient is receiving pain medication and has a plan to continue pain management.
* Liver function abnormalities: The patient is receiving lactulose and ciprofloxacin for prophylaxis, and his liver transplant is being planned.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

* Respiratory failure: Pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and respiratory failure due to chronic lung disease.
* Renal failure: Acute kidney injury (AKI), chronic kidney disease (CKD), and electrolyte imbalances.
* Liver failure: Hepatic encephalopathy, ascites, and coagulopathy.
* Nutritional deficiencies: Malnutrition, electrolyte imbalances, and impaired wound healing.
* Infections: Pneumonia, sepsis, and bloodstream infections.
* Cardiovascular complications: Hypertension, cardiac arrhythmias, and cardiac failure.

The patient's prognosis is poor due to his critical illness and the complexity of his medical conditions.

Summary:

The patient is a 30-year-old male who is critically ill with respiratory failure, acute renal failure, and liver failure. He is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation. His respiratory failure is multifactorial, including acute volume overload, chronic renal failure, pulmonary hypertension, portopulmonary hypertension, and atelectasis due to abdominal distension. He is receiving diuresis and is being considered for weaning drips and extubation.

His acute renal failure is suspected to be either ATN or HRS type 1, and he is receiving midodrine and octreotide. He is listed for liver transplant and is receiving lactulose and ciprofloxacin for prophylaxis. His nutritional support includes tube feeds and NovaSource Renal (Full) at 10 mL/hour.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial and may worsen if not managed properly. He may experience further respiratory distress, hypoxia, and hypercapnia.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure may progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed properly. He may experience further fluid overload, electrolyte imbalances, and acidosis.
3. Liver Failure: The patient's liver failure may worsen if not managed properly. He may experience further encephalopathy, bleeding, and infection.
4. Sepsis: The patient's immunosuppressed state and presence of central lines and dialysis catheters may increase his risk of developing sepsis.
5. Bleeding: The patient's liver failure and use of anticoagulants may increase his risk of bleeding.
6. Infection: The patient's immunosuppressed state and presence of central lines and dialysis catheters may increase his risk of developing infection.
7. Fluid Overload: The patient's acute renal failure and use of diuretics may lead to fluid overload if not managed properly.
8. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient's acute renal failure and use of diuretics may lead to electrolyte imbalances if not managed properly.
9. Acidosis: The patient's acute renal failure and use of diuretics may lead to acidosis if not managed properly.
10. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's liver failure and use of anticoagulants may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

   Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**] is a 30 year old gentleman with biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (25 years ago) complicated by recurrent cirrhosis,
   hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension,
   post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome and asthma admitted peritonitis
   s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory failure
   and increased work of breathing requiring intubation, now with improved
   respiratory status and post extubation yesterday.
   1) HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY Failue: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing in setting of chronic hypoxia with AA
   gradient.
    *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Parenchymal opacities likely due to pulmonary edema, with CXR
   improved/stable and prelim neg cx from BAL. 3L fluid off yesterday.
   Resolution of alkalosis. ABG stable/with high PaO2 on low AC settings,
   will attempt PSV this AM, with potential extubation this PM. In order
   to optimize his respiratory status, we will continue CVVH with -150
   cc/hr.
   - Wean vent to PSV this AM, with potential extubation this PM
   - Continue CVVH today with ?HD in future, continue net negative. Follow
   up renal recs.
   - Wean sedation as tolerated, restraints as needed for now.
    2) GI DYSMOTILITY, with abdominal distention, TF residuals. KUB no
   evidence of obstruction, large amount of stool in colon, but large BM
   this AM.
   - Tube feeds restarted. Advance toward goal of 50 cc/hr as tolerated.
   Hold for residuals over 150
   - PRN Reglan
   - Titrate lactulose to [**12-28**] BM per day
   - KUB today
   3) CIRRHOSIS: Patient with history of biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on
   transplant list. Liver following. [**Month (only) 8**] need PCP prophylaxis given
   patient with PCP on floor and his immunocompromised state on tacro. No
   PCP [**Name9 (PRE) 1992**] per ID.
    - Cont cipro prophylaxis and clotimazole troche.
   - TacroFK level daily, with 0.5 mg daily for now. Coordinate
   administration/level check timing with pharmacy.
   - Cont lactulose, as per above.
   - Trend LFTs.
    4) RENAL FAILURE: Patient with history of post-strep GN now with acute
   on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   CVVH started [**2135-7-15**]. Continue CVVH for now to optimize respiratory
   status in peri-extubation setting. Once fluid status is optimized, can
   likely go forward with intermittent HD. D/C'd HRS regimen.
   - Continue CVVH, with goal of  -150 cc/hr.
   - Trend chem-7 [**Name8 (MD) 77**] RN for CRT labs
   5) Thrombocytopenia: slowly trending down over past week, generally
   stable in past few days. Not likely due to HIT since he has been on
   heparin for >2 weeks (HIT is usually within 2-14 days) and he has
   remained stable despite being continued on heparin. Withhold HITT
   workup if remains stable.
   - Cont to trend plts
    6) Coagulopathy: Elevated PTT, stable now. No active signs of bleeding
   or thrombosis.
    - Cont to trend PTT
   7) ANEMIA: Patient with intermittent transfusion requirement, with last
   transfusion requirement on [**7-14**] (1 unit PRBC).  Likely has chronic
   anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct stable.
   - Trend hct Q24H, transfuse hct<21.

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the patient's condition and potential medical complications:

Patient's Condition:

* The patient is a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant, and recurrent cirrhosis.
* He has undergone liver transplant 25 years ago and has developed recurrent cirrhosis.
* He has also developed hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious glomerulonephritis, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma.
* He was admitted with peritonitis and was transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory failure and increased work of breathing requiring intubation.
* He was successfully extubated yesterday and is currently on Clotrimazole troche per transplant recommendations.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure:
	* The patient has a history of chronic hypoxia with an arterial-alveolar (A-a) gradient.
	* He has developed parenchymal opacities likely due to pulmonary edema, which may worsen his respiratory status.
	* He is at risk for reintubation and prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Gastrointestinal Dysmotility:
	* The patient has abdominal distention and TF residuals, which may indicate gastrointestinal dysmotility.
	* He is at risk for bowel obstruction, perforation, or bleeding.
3. Cirrhosis:
	* The patient has a history of recurrent cirrhosis, which may worsen his liver function and increase his risk of bleeding, encephalopathy, and liver failure.
	* He is at risk for portal hypertension, which may worsen his respiratory and gastrointestinal symptoms.
4. Renal Failure:
	* The patient has acute on sub-acute renal failure, which may worsen his electrolyte imbalance and increase his risk of bleeding and infection.
	* He is at risk for chronic kidney disease and end-stage renal disease.
5. Thrombocytopenia:
	* The patient has a history of thrombocytopenia, which may worsen his risk of bleeding.
	* He is at risk for disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and bleeding.
6. Coagulopathy:
	* The patient has a prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT), which may worsen his risk of bleeding.
	* He is at risk for bleeding and thrombosis.
7. Anemia:
	* The patient has a history of anemia, which may worsen his fatigue and increase his risk of bleeding.
	* He is at risk for chronic anemia and transfusion-dependent anemia.

Based on the patient's condition and potential medical complications, it is essential to closely monitor his respiratory, gastrointestinal, and renal function, as well as his coagulation and bleeding status. Additionally, the patient's liver function and electrolyte balance should be closely monitored to prevent complications such as liver failure and electrolyte imbalance.

   and increased work of breathing requiring intubation, now with improved
   respiratory status and post extubation yesterday but with low grade
   fever and inc WBC today.
   # HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing at admission, in setting of chronic
   hypoxia with AA gradient.
    *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Parenchymal opacities on past imaging likely due to pulmonary edema,
   with CXR improved/stable and prelim neg cx from BAL. -150 cc/hr off
   yesterday. Successful extubation with stable SpO2 yesterday.
   *New low grade fever and leukocytosis yesterday. Ddx includes new
   pneumonia vs. SBP vs. other infection (?line). Will panculture, CXR,
   and IR paracentesis today.
   *We continued CVVH yesterday in order to optimize his respiratory
   status, but now that he appears to have had resolution of much of his
   peripheral edema, we can likely D/C CVVH today and transition to
   intermittent HD.
   -CXR this AM.
   -BCx from each line, UCx, sputum cx, stool C. diff toxin.
   -Diagnostic IR paracentesis.
   # FEVER AND LEUKOCYTOSIS: As per above, ddx includes new pneumonia vs.
   SBP vs. other infection (?line).
   -As per above, panculture, CXR, and IR paracentesis today.
   # GI DYSMOTILITY: With baseline mild-mod abdominal distention s/p
   ex-lap, now with frequency loose stool. Will check C diff, as per
   above, in setting of fever, though loose stool is likely due to
   aggressive bowel regimen.  Currently NPO after removal of NGT with
   extubation; we can advance diet slowly as tolerated.

   - Advance diet slowly as tolerated.

   on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   CVVH started [**2135-7-15**]. Fluid status is now optimized, so we can D/C CVVH

Summary:

Mr. [**Known lastname 8404**], a 30-year-old gentleman with a complex medical history, including biliary atresia, liver transplant, and multiple comorbidities, was admitted to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory failure and increased work of breathing. He was intubated and required invasive ventilation. He was successfully extubated yesterday and is currently on oxygen therapy.

The patient has a history of recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious GN, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma. He is currently experiencing low-grade fever and leukocytosis, which may be related to a new infection, sepsis, or other causes.

The patient's respiratory status has improved, but he still requires oxygen therapy. His liver function is abnormal, and he has a history of chronic rejection. He is on the transplant list and is receiving treatment for his liver disease.

The patient has acute renal failure, likely secondary to ATN or HRS type 1, and is receiving CVVH. He is also experiencing thrombocytopenia, coagulopathy, and anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Infection: The patient's low-grade fever and leukocytosis may indicate a new infection, which could worsen his respiratory and hepatic function.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's history of chronic respiratory disease and current respiratory failure make him prone to further respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
3. Liver failure: The patient's liver function is abnormal, and he has a history of chronic rejection. Further liver damage or failure could occur, leading to increased mortality.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen, leading to further electrolyte imbalances, acidosis, and increased mortality.
5. Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia make him prone to bleeding complications, which could worsen his respiratory and hepatic function.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to further respiratory and cardiac complications.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's history of gastrointestinal disease and current abdominal distension make him prone to further gastrointestinal complications, such as bowel obstruction or perforation.
8. Sepsis: The patient's low-grade fever and leukocytosis may indicate sepsis, which could worsen his respiratory and hepatic function.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue oxygen therapy and monitor the patient's respiratory status closely.
2. Investigate the cause of the patient's fever and leukocytosis, including panculture, CXR, and IR paracentesis.
3. Manage the patient's liver disease with lactulose and titrate the dose to achieve a goal blood level of [**2-28**].
4. Continue CVVH and transition to intermittent HD when the patient's fluid status is optimized.
5. Monitor the patient's platelet count and trend it regularly.
6. Continue to manage the patient's coagulopathy and anemia with appropriate medications and transfusions.
7. Advance the patient's diet slowly as tolerated and monitor his gastrointestinal function closely.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and acid-base status closely.

   s/p ex-lap now transferred to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory failure
   and increased work of breathing requiring intubation, now with improved
   respiratory status and post extubation yesterday but with low grade
   fever and inc WBC today.
   # HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Multiple reasons for worsening hypoxia
   and increased work of breathing at admission, in setting of chronic
   hypoxia with AA gradient.
    *Baseline low PaO2 of 70s likely due to impaired VQ mm due to known
   stable L pleural effusion and from atelectasis from ascites.  Also
   shunt from known hepatopulmonary syndrome.
   *Parenchymal opacities on past imaging likely due to pulmonary edema,
   with CXR improved/stable and prelim neg cx from BAL. -150 cc/hr off
   yesterday. Successful extubation with stable SpO2 yesterday.
   *New low grade fever and leukocytosis yesterday. Ddx includes new
   pneumonia vs. SBP vs. other infection (?line). Will panculture, CXR,
   and IR paracentesis today.
   *We continued CVVH yesterday in order to optimize his respiratory
   status, but now that he appears to have had resolution of much of his
   peripheral edema, we can likely D/C CVVH today and transition to
   intermittent HD.
   -CXR this AM.
   -BCx from each line, UCx, sputum cx, stool C. diff toxin.
   -Diagnostic paracentesis.
   # FEVER AND LEUKOCYTOSIS: As per above, ddx includes new pneumonia vs.
   SBP vs. other infection (?line). Will panculture, CXR, and IR
   paracentesis today.
   # GI DYSMOTILITY: With baseline mild-mod abdominal distention s/p
   ex-lap, now with frequency loose stool. Will check C diff, as per
   above, in setting of fever, though loose stool is likely due to
   aggressive bowel regimen.  Currently NPO after removal of NGT with
   extubation; we can advance diet slowly as tolerated.
   - C. diff toxin, as per above.
   - Advance diet slowly as tolerated.
   -Titrate lactulose to [**12-28**] BM per day.
   # CIRRHOSIS: Patient with history of biliary atresia s/p liver
   transplant (age 4) complicated by chronic rejection. Currently on
   transplant list. Liver following. Per ID, no need for PCP [**Name Initial (PRE) 2000**].
    - Cont cipro prophylaxis and clotimazole troche.
   - TacroFK level daily, with 0.5 mg daily this AM and goal blood level
   [**2-28**].
   - Cont lactulose, as per above.
   - Trend LFTs.
   # RENAL FAILURE: Patient with history of post-strep GN now with acute
   on sub-acute renal failure likely secondary to ATN versus HRS type 1.
   CVVH started [**2135-7-15**]. Fluid status is now optimized, so we can D/C CVVH
   and transition to intermittent HD. D/C'd HRS regimen.
   - As per above, D/C CVVH today. Transition to HD.
   #  THROMBOCYTOPENIA: Slowly trending down over past week, nowe
   generally stable to improved. Not likely due to HIT since he has been
   on heparin for >2 weeks (HIT is usually within 2-14 days) and plts have
   remained stable despite being continued on heparin. Withhold HIT workup
   if remains stable.
   - Cont to trend plts
    #  COAGULOPATHY: Elevated PTT in the setting of cirrhotic
   coagulopathy, stable now. No active signs of bleeding or thrombosis.
    - Cont to trend PTT
   #  ANEMIA: Patient with intermittent transfusion requirement, with last
   transfusion requirement on [**7-14**] (1 unit PRBC).  Likely has chronic
   anemia from liver and renal failure. Hct stable.
   - Trend hct Q24H, transfuse hct<21.
   # FEN: Restart PO as tolerated, as per above. ISS for glycemic control.
   #  ACCESS:
   -PICC Line - [**2135-7-15**] 07:41 PM
   -Dialysis Catheter - [**2135-7-15**] 09:13 PM
   -Arterial Line - [**2135-7-15**] 10:11 PM
   # PPx: PPI, pneumoboots, heparin.
   # COMMUNICATION: his father, [**Name (NI) 8405**]
   # DISPOSITION: C/o to floor pending above this afternoon (24H after
   extubation) pending above if he remains stable.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Food today as tolerated.
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2135-7-15**] 07:41 PM
   Dialysis Catheter - [**2135-7-15**] 09:13 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2135-7-15**] 10:11 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots, SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: PPI
   Communication:  his father, [**Name (NI) 8405**]

   Disposition: C/o to floor pending above this afternoon (24H after
   extubation) pending above if he remains stable.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient, a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant, and various comorbidities, has been admitted to the MICU for hypoxic respiratory failure and increased work of breathing. The patient has been intubated and is currently on invasive ventilation.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient's respiratory status has improved with successful extubation yesterday, with stable SpO2 levels.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's cardiovascular system is stable, with a normal heart rate and blood pressure.
* Renal: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) and is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH), which will be discontinued and replaced with intermittent hemodialysis (HD) once the patient's fluid status is optimized.
* Liver: The patient has cirrhosis and is on the transplant list. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are trending towards normalization.
* Hematology: The patient has thrombocytopenia, but it is not likely due to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). The patient's platelet count is trending towards normalization.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure may worsen, requiring further interventions such as non-invasive ventilation or mechanical ventilation.
* Renal failure: The patient's AKI may progress to chronic kidney disease (CKD) if not managed properly.
* Liver failure: The patient's cirrhosis may worsen, leading to complications such as portal hypertension, variceal bleeding, and encephalopathy.
* Infection: The patient's low-grade fever and leukocytosis may indicate a new infection, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
* Gastrointestinal (GI) complications: The patient's GI dysmotility may lead to further complications such as bowel obstruction, perforation, or bleeding.

Based on the patient's current status and potential complications, the plan of care includes:

* Continuous monitoring of the patient's vital signs and laboratory results.
* Optimization of the patient's fluid status and electrolyte balance.
* Management of the patient's respiratory status, including the use of non-invasive ventilation or mechanical ventilation if necessary.
* Management of the patient's AKI, including the use of CVVH or HD.
* Monitoring of the patient's liver function and LFTs.
* Evaluation and treatment of the patient's GI dysmotility.
* Further evaluation and treatment of the patient's low-grade fever and leukocytosis.

The patient's disposition is pending, with a plan to transfer him to the floor if he remains stable and meets the criteria for transfer.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health status as follows:

* The patient is a 30-year-old male with a history of biliary atresia, liver transplant, and multiple comorbidities, including recurrent cirrhosis, hepato-pulmonary syndrome, porto-pulmonary hypertension, post-infectious glomerulonephritis, nephrotic syndrome, and asthma.
* The patient was admitted with peritonitis and hypoxic respiratory failure, requiring intubation. He was successfully extubated yesterday and is now post-extubation.
* The patient's respiratory status has improved, with stable SpO2 levels and decreased respiratory rate.
* He has a low-grade fever and increased white blood cell count, which may indicate a new infection or sepsis.
* The patient has chronic liver dysfunction and is on immunosuppressive therapy.
* He has acute renal failure, which is likely secondary to acute tubular necrosis or hepatorenal syndrome type 1.
* The patient has thrombocytopenia, which is not likely due to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).
* He has coagulopathy, which is stable and not causing active bleeding or thrombosis.
* The patient has anemia, which is likely due to chronic liver and renal failure.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Sepsis or septic shock due to the new infection or sepsis
* Respiratory failure or worsening hypoxia
* Acute kidney injury or worsening renal failure
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to chronic liver dysfunction
* Increased risk of bleeding or thrombosis due to coagulopathy and thrombocytopenia
* Development of chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease
* Further deterioration of liver function leading to liver failure

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continued monitoring of respiratory status and oxygen saturation
* Investigation of the new infection or sepsis, including panculture, CXR, and IR paracentesis
* Optimization of fluid status and transition to intermittent hemodialysis
* Monitoring of liver function and coagulopathy
* Titration of immunosuppressive therapy to achieve optimal blood levels
* Management of anemia and transfusion requirements
* Close monitoring of the patient's overall condition and potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 64-inch tall, 70-kg male who was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and acute liver failure. He was successfully extubated 24 hours ago and is currently on nasal cannula oxygen at 50% FiO2. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.3C, heart rate of 106 bpm, and blood pressure of 144/87 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 36 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 95%. He has a central venous pressure of 9 mmHg and is receiving calcium gluconate and potassium chloride through CRRT.

The patient's laboratory results show acute kidney injury with a creatinine level of 1.4 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen level of 29 mg/dL. His liver function tests are abnormal, with an aspartate transaminase level of 40 IU/L and an alanine transaminase level of 13 IU/L. His albumin level is 2.9 g/dL, and his lactate level is 1.6 mmol/L.

The patient's medications include prograf, heparin sodium, and calcium gluconate. He is receiving nutrition through a nasogastric tube and has a PICC line, dialysis catheter, and arterial line in place.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if his oxygen saturation drops or if he develops respiratory acidosis.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed properly.
3. Liver failure: The patient's liver failure may lead to coagulopathy, bleeding, and encephalopathy if not managed properly.
4. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his immunosuppressed state and the presence of invasive lines and catheters.
5. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to his acute kidney injury and liver failure.
6. Cardiac complications: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may indicate cardiac complications, such as cardiomyopathy or arrhythmias.
7. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's nasogastric tube and nutritional support may lead to gastrointestinal complications, such as diarrhea or constipation.
8. Neurological complications: The patient's liver failure and sepsis may lead to neurological complications, such as encephalopathy or seizures.
